characters: VIEWED FROM FAR BACK IN THE CHURCH
AT THE BACK OF THE CAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white cross on the church steeple stands against blue The church bell rings, resonating. Mass has let out. Small church, small congregation. The d road in front is lined with pick-up trucks and parishione foot heading to outlying farms and homes. An old two-stor house sits across the road. Lone. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight comes through the soot on the windows, more brow bright. SOMERSET, 45, in a suit and tie, stands in this e second-story room. He looks around, at the ceiling, at th wooden floor, at the peeling wallpaper on the walls. Somerset walks to one wall where the current wallpaper is away to reveal flowery wallpaper underneath. He runs his across one of the pale red roses that decorates the older He pushes the grime away, brings the rose out more clearl He pulls at the edge of the paper, carefully ripping off roughly squared section with the rose at its center. He studies it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds sing. Somerset stands, pondering the forested lands

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is something wrong? Somerset does not respond. The MAN, in an ill-fitting rea estate jacket, is seated on the hood of a dirty Ford Thunderbird. He holds a check and a booklet of receipts.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No... no. There's nothing wrong. Somerset still seems distant.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (writes receipt) Not that it's any of my business... but, are you figuring on moving out here eventually?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I just never seen a man mortgaging an empty house before.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Everything here still seems... seems so strange to me. All this.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'd say this place is about as normal as places get. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 2 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ The man walks over to hand over a receipt. Somerset accep receipt, folds it. Somerset smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: That is exactly what I mean. Strange. Somerset looks back at the house. The man does not unders

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset is in a window seat, smoking a cigarette, lookin the speeding train. He is near the back of the car, away the few other passengers. Outside, farms, small homes and lawns pass. The entire pa is dappled by the rays of the soon setting sun. The light flickers across Somerset's placid face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is nearly full. Somerset has his suitcase on th aisle seat beside him. He has a hardcover book unopened o lap. He still stares out the window, but his disposition soured. The train is passing an ugly, swampy field. A car's burnt-out skeleton sits rusting in the bracken. A further on, two dogs are fighting, circling, attacking, t coats matted with blood. Somerset turns his head to watch the dogs. Away in the field, another dog sprints to join the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing urban streets below. Slums. Smashed cars. People stand on the corners, under the bleak glow of street lamp Somerset's suitcase is by the window. Somerset is now in aisle seat, reading his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains closed. The SOUNDS of the CITY are here as they be everywhere in this story. A CAR ALARM SHRIEKS. Somerse life is packed in many moving boxes, except for clothing closet and hundreds of books on shelves. Somerset, dressed only in his underwear, lays back on the He reaches to the nightstand, to a wooden, pyramidical metronome. He frees the metronome's weighted swingarm so it moves ba http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ forth. Swings to the left... TICK, swings to the right... Tick, tick, tick, measured and steady. Somerset situates on the bed, closes his eyes. The metron ticking competes with the sound of the car alarm. Somerse face tightens as he concentrates on the metronome. His eyes close tighter. Tick, tick, tick... the swingarm moves evenly. Somerset's breathing deepens. The car ALARM seems QUIETER. Tick, tick, tick. Somerset continues his concentration. The METRONOME is the ONLY SOUND. Somerset's face relaxes slightly as he begins to fall asleep. Tick, tick, tick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID MILLS, 31, exits with a bagged 400z bottle of beer. a lean, attractive man, constantly coiled, eyes always smoldering. FOLLOW as he walks quickly past iron-gated storefronts. He crosses the street under elevated subway tracks. A train roars overhead. Mills watches it as he walks on. Blue sparks spit off the third rail and illuminate Mills, throwing his shadow long down the deserted street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rotting neighborhood lives in the shadow of a single skyscraper. Mills walks, looks at the broken refrigerator pieces of junk in the gutter. Ahead in the street, TWO YOUNG THUGS struggle with a crow break into the trunk of a parked car. Mills draws near. One thug looks up, doesn't think Mills be a problem, continues prying. Mills stops, calm.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Is that your car, man?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST THUG
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you care? Mills pauses, switches his beer bottle to his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Does that car belong to you? The thugs look at each other, gauging. They face Mills.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST THUG
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Yeah, it's my car, alright? Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You're telling me that's your car? The second thug starts the long way round the car.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND THUG
dialogues.text: Well, for some strange reason, I don't believe you. Mills gives a â€œisn't that silly" laugh, shifts his gaze - Sees the first thug slide the crowbar so it's held as a w

dialogues.speaker: FIRST THUG
dialogues.text: (steps forward) You can fucking suck my... Mills swiftly finishes that sentence by smashing his bott against the first thug's head. The thug falls, swings bli The second thug moves from the side, brings out a knife. Mills averts, swings, pounds the side of his fist into th second thug's face -- CRACK. Broken nose. The second thug stumbles back, drops the knife, his nose squirting blood. Mills turns, enraged, breathing hard. The first thug is screaming, trying to stand. Mills takes step, punts the first thug's head. The crowbar clatters a Mills is in the process of kicking a man when he's down, the second thug grabs him from behind, pulls him backward Mills clutches at the thug's arm, trying to avoid a choke They both struggle spastically. The thug's winning. Gurgling, gasping for air, Mills shifts his weight, drops knee and spins the thug, slamming him against the car. Mills breaks loose, grabs a handful of the second thug's and holds the man's head against the car's side window. M free hand pounds the thug's face: once, twice -- third ti the charm as the window shatters. The thug goes out cold. Mills backs off, still incensed. He rubs his throat, look the two prone men. Slowly, he regains some composure. He takes a keychain from his pocket. He unlocks the door car, loads one of the thugs into the back seat. He walks collect the other thug off the street. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset picks items off a moving box: keys, wallet, homi badge. Finally, he opens the hardcover book from the trai From the pages, he takes the pale, wallpaper rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall is stained by a starburst of blood. Somerset stand melancholy, looking at a body on the floor under a sheet sawed-off shotgun. The apartment is gloomy. DETECTIVE TAY 52, looks through a notepad.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Neighbors heard them screaming at each other. It was nothing new or unusual. But, then they heard the gun go off. Boom, boom... both barrels.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Did his wife confess? Did she actually speak the words?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: When the patrolman got here she was trying to put his head back together. She was crying too hard to say anything. (shuts notebook) Crime of passion.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Yes. Look at all the passion splattered up on the wall here. Taylor shifts his weight, impatient, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: This is a done deal. All but the paperwork. Somerset looks at a coloring-book open on the coffee tabl There are crayons beside it. Somerset picks the book up. He flips through: crudely colored pictures.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Did their son see it happen?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that? Huh? (pointing) He's dead. His wife killed him. There it is. That's all. Anything else has nothing to do with nothing. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset replaces the book, digs up a cigarette from his

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You and your fucking questions, Somerset. I'm glad I'm getting rid of you today. You know that, you fuck? David Mills enters, dressed in a suit. He looks a bit los

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Uh... Lieutenant Somerset? Somerset lights his cigarette, looks to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I'm David Mills... your new partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A body-bag is carried through the crowd around the teneme doors. Somerset follows. Mills follows Somerset. They wal towards the end of the filthy block.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'ma little thrown. I just finished orientation at central, and they dumped me off down here.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I heard you brought in two small-timers last night.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Two real idiots.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Since we are just starting out, I thought we could go to a bar. Sit and talk for awhile. That way we can...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but I'd rather start sniffing for a case, if it's all the same to you. Seeing how we only have a week for this whole transition thing. (waits) I want to get into the shit a.s.a.p., know what I mean? Somerset walks, no reply. Mills searches to get a read on

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I meant to ask you something... when we spoke on the phone. I can't help wondering... (pause) http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (wary) I... I don't follow.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: All this effort you've gone through, to be transferred from Philadelphia to here. It's the first question that pops into my head. Mills formulates his response.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'm here for the same reasons as you, I guess. Or... at least the same reasons you used to have for being here... (cutting) ...before you decided to give up. Somerset stops and faces Mills.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You think you know me? You just met me two minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't understand the question.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It's very simple. You've come from the "City of Brotherly Love" to the "City of Brotherly Hate," detective. I've never seen it done that way.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe I thought I could do more good here than there. (pause) You know, it'd be great by me if we didn't start right out kicking each other in the balls. But, you're calling the shots, lieutenant, so however you want it to go.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Let me tell you how I want this to go. I want you to look, and I want you to listen.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I wasn't standing around Philly guarding the fucking Liberty Bell.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: But, you've never worked homicide in http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ this city.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I realize that.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Well, please do me the favor of remembering it. Mills just stares back at Somerset. Somerset walks. Mills rolls his eyes, looks to heaven like, "what'd I do to des this?" He follows Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset lies asleep on the bed. It is still dark outside Relatively quiet. The PHONE beside the inactive metronome HARSHLY. Somerset awakens suddenly, rankled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is barely becoming light outside. Mills can't sleep. Alone in a double bed. He sits up, frustrated. Sits on th edge of the bed and looks around. The room is a shambles, filled with moving boxes. The light coming through the window glows upon a football on one box. Large and noble, a golden player stands in fr motion at the trophy's pinnacle. Mills looks at the trophy and a fond smile forms on his f The CLINKING of DISHES and SILVERWARE is HEARD from anoth room. Mills looks at the closed bedroom door, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across a living room full of boxes, TRACY MILLS, 30, a be woman, stands in her bathrobe. She's upset about somethin takes dishes out of boxes, puts them on the kitchenette c She pulls a mug from a clump of newspaper and pours some from a pot on the stove. Blowing on the steaming tea, she back on the counter, looks over at the closed bedroom doo The tea is too hot to sip, and as Tracy is placing the mu the counter behind her the PHONE RINGS. Startled, she rel the mug too close to the edge. It falls -- Crashes to the floor, shatters. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark hall. Somerset and Mills stand with OFFICER DAVIS, beefy, uniformed cop. Light from a camera's flash spills from the nearby kitchen. Davis hands Somerset two flashli

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: At what time did you confirm the death?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Like I said, we didn't touch anything, but we were on scene at like o-five- hundred, so he's had his face in a plate of spaghetti for about half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait. You didn't check him? You didn't check vital signs?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Believe me, he's gone. Unless he's breathing spaghetti sauce now.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: No. The point is, when you're first man in, you check vital signs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: This guy's sitting in a pile of his own shit and piss. If he ain't dead he would have stood up by now.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (getting angry) Listen, Godzilla... Somerset steps in, heads Mills off.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Thank you, Officer Davis. We'll see you again after we've had a look.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Davis leaves, eyeing Mills. Mills watches him. Somerset h Mills a flashlight, takes out surgical gloves.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I wonder what exactly was the point of the conversation you were about to get into?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: And, I wonder how many times Officer Davis there has found a supposedly dead http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ man who didn't really die until Davis was back in the patrol car calling the morgue and eating a powdered donut. Somerset snaps one glove over his hand and checks the fit

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Drop it. We have more important concerns just now, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Fine... for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER packs up, hoists his camera and equipment bag. Somerset and Mills enter. Mills puts on hi pair of rubber gloves. The grubby kitchen is small; barel for four people to move around in. The photographer exits

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Bon appetit. The only light is a murky green illumination from the cei The light bathes an OBESE MAN who is slumped forward in a kitchen chair, face-down-dead in a plate of spaghetti. The sizable kitchen table's green tablecloth is covered w soiled paper plates. The plates hold bits of half-eaten sandwiches, potatoes, donuts and other junk-food remnants Mills and Somerset turn on their flashlights. Mills point at the green bulb above. Aluminum foil has been wrapped a the bulb to focus the light on the corpse. Somerset sweeps the room with his flashlight. He goes to body and kneels beside it. There's a rope tied around the man's wide gut. Mills comes to stand beside Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I guess that makes it homicide. Somerset crouches lower, uses a pen to lift one of the de man's pants cuffs. Rope is tied around the purplish ankle Mills examines the knots behind the chair's back. Shines flashlight on the man's belly.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Still, he could have tied himself in. To make it look like murder. Somerset isn't listening, focused on the corpse. He studi man's head and neck without touching.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker I don't see any blood or bruises yet. No wounds. You see anything?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (irritated) Not yet. Somerset stands, points his flashlight: the obese man's s hands are clutching utensils. A knife in the left hand, a sticking straight up in the right with a hunk of meat han skewered. Cockroaches swarm. Mills turns to the sink and stove. Each burner of the sto a used pot or pan on it. There's food slopped everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I saw a guy once... committed suicide, but he wanted to make sure his family could collect insurance money, right? Somerset walks to the room's only window. The window has painted over with black paint. he touches the window with pinkie finger. The paint is still wet. Mills goes to a trash can by the refrigerator. The trash full to the brim with empty food containers.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: So, this guy took this big knife... and he held it behind him, put the tip of it in his back, and he ran backwards into the wall. Cause, he thought it was going to look like someone stabbed him in the back. Mills opens the refrigerator. It's nearly empty.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Except, he poked a big fucking hole in the dry wall when he did it.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: If you could... spare me the anecdotes for now. Leave the refrigerator open for the light.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh, forgive me. I thought we had this male-bonding thing going. My mistake. Somerset looks at the floor, deep in thought. His flashli beam follows a trail of dripped sauces, soups and bits of running from the stove to the table.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: What do you smell? Other than him, and http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 12 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ all the food.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (sniffs) I don't know... there's something. Somerset goes close to the table, then leans to peer unde

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: A bucket. Somerset points the flashlight and Mills crouches, pulls tablecloth on his side of the table. Two large dead rats the floor beside a metal bucket. Mills grimaces, slides under the table, careful to avoid rats. He looks in the bucket. He leans back, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It's vomit. He looks at Somerset under the table.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It's a bucket of vomit.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Is there any blood in it?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Can't tell by looking. Somerset stands, perplexed, stares at the dead man. There knock at the door. The detectives look to DOCTOR THOMAS O'NEILL, 52, the medical examiner. O'Neill is a frumpy ma seems a bit gone, looking at the green bulb.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEILL
dialogues.text: Mood lighting. Very sixties. He drops his bag on the floor, sorts through the contents

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) You think he was poisoned? Mills goes to the trash can, pokes the garbage with a pen

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: And, those rats there somehow ate the poison off the floor?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Guessing this early is useless.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEILL
dialogues.text: You girls have got the forensics guys http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ out there chompin' at the bit. Don't know if we'll all fit in here though. Mills continues searching the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: There's room. Light's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Well, three is certainly a crowd in here. And, with four, someone's bound to be stepping on evidence. (pause) Detective Mills, go help the officers question the neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (not pleased) Thanks, but no thanks. I'll stay on this. Somerset watches O'Neill at the corpse. O'Neill points a flashlight with his mouth, his hands free for the examina

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Send one forensic in on your way out. Mills is pissed. He lifts his flashlight to shine it on t side of Somerset's face. A moment passes. Somerset looks at Mills, light shining directly in Somerset's eyes. A longer moment. Mills switc the light off. He leaves. O'Neill unceremoniously places both hands on the dead man head, lifts the swollen visage from the spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEILL
dialogues.text: He is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THWACK, THWACK... THWACK. Mills punches the heavy bag wit hard, quick punches. Sweat drips off his face. He's in wo out clothing, a bundle of nerves wearing boxing gloves. The walls are covered in mirrors. Other cops watch Mills they pass, checking out the new kid. Mills keeps punching skillfully. He stops when he sees Somerset reflected in one of the mi Somerset walks over, carrying a pizza box with paper pile top. He sits on a near bench, takes out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker Pizza and paperwork, Detective Mills.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: We need to chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills opens a door and enters with Somerset behind. They alone. Chairs face an old, limp-roped boxing ring. Practi pads hang from pegs on a wall. Mills clasps a pair in his gloves, offers them to Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You just hold them up. I do all the work. Somerset takes the pads reluctantly, puts them on. He sti the un-lit cigarette hanging from his mouth. Mills climbs the ring. He holds the ropes open for Somerset, waits. Somerset doesn't want to do this, but he climbs up.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You've seen my files... seen the things I've done?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Yes. Impressive work. Mills motions to Somerset and Somerset holds up the pract pads. Mills starts working them, lightly, warming up. THWACK... THWACK...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: So, what's your problem? I've done my time on door-to-doors, and walking a beat.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I know it. That doesn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I did all that shit a long time ago. THWACK... THWACK... Somerset's very stiff, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I made a decision, because I have to worry about the integrity of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|

Page 15 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ When I'm on scene, I'm not going to worry whether you think you're getting enough time on the playing field. I'm there to do the work. Mills punches a little more aggressively. Somerset's back flinching, keeping the pads high. THWACK... THWACK... THW

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: The badge in my pocket says "detective," just like yours. I've been Homicide for four and a half years.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You've worked Homicide for four years, or for five years... Don't count the half-years, unless you want to sound like a rookie. Mills unloads a mighty wallop and one practice pad recoil Somerset's face, knocks Somerset on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Oops. My hand slipped. Mills walks, climbs out of the ring.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You fucked me over today, and you know it. You know it. Somerset looks at the broken cigarette in his mouth. He contains his anger. He seems to realize Mills has a point

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Just don't jerk me off. That's all I ask. It's not much. Don't jerk me off. (pause) Please, do me the favor of remembering that. Mills exits. Somerset spits out the broken cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks out a window from behind steel bars. Below her, young children play in a playground. They're p hop-scotch, throwing balls, chasing each other. The swing are broken. The handball wall is graffitied.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Mills. We don't have anything right now. Tracy looks away from the window to the haggard WOMAN. Th http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ school's office is ill-equipped, busy, disorganized.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: We'll try to give you a call if we need substitutes next month.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Tracy looks back at the playground: on the other side of chain-link fence, a butcher in a bloody apron walks down ramp of a freezer truck. he carries a big, whole, slaught pig on his shoulder. The pig's head flops as the butcher walks. Some children their games and run to watch the man and the pig corpse p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train clatters through a tunnel, packed full, WHEELS SCREECHING. The lights go on and off. Passengers read tabloids, stare at their feet, study advertisements on th walls; anything to avoid making eye-contact with others. All races, creeds and colors; all ugly, forlorn human bei Tracy stands fatigued, holding a handrail. A bag-lady, crusted with dirt, reeking, pushes her way th the crowd. A man presses against Tracy in an attempt to l bag-lady pass. Tracy switches hands on the rail, turns si to make room. She looks down. On one seat, a man, quite normal looking, sits holding a magazine, THREE-WAY FUCK, in one hand. His other hand is pocket. He's obviously masturbating himself in his pants. one else notices or seems to care. Tracy looks away, disgusted. She closes her eyes. The tra wheels SCREECH LOUDER as the train takes a curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

A STRANGE MAN, 20, stands at the edge of the ca He wears a stained sweatsuit outfit and hums a song, obli Tracy and Mills look together over the piles of fruits an vegetables piled on wooden stands which form tight aisles

dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Mills holds his thumb and forefinger about a quarter of a apart to illustrate.

Tracy looks up fro heads of lettuce to the strange man at the entrance. The strange man hums on, rocking back and forth slowly, h glassy. Customers come and go, paying him no mind. Mills notices Tracy's interest. He keeps comparing carrot

dialogues.text: Name that tune? Anybody name that tune? Name that tune... The man keeps repeating this, over and over, still ignore

dialogues.text: That's what it's like. Like they just gave up, and let everyone out. Mills nods, his back to Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (CONT)

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: There are a lot of frightening people in the world. Tracy looks again to the strange man.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGE MAN
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Name that tune? Anybody name that tune?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It seems worse than Philadelphia, because everything is pushed right up against you. In your face. Mills edges past Tracy towards the front of the store, tr be pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Listen, honey. I don't want to fight tonight. Okay? Can we just go one night without fighting about something? He looks over apples, thinks that's the end of that.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to start a fight. (pause) How am I trying to start a fight?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: We're here now. Okay. Are we supposed to pack it all in and go back? How are we going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Do I have to act like I love this place? Is that what a "good wife" would do?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (doleful) There's a lot of pressure on me... I...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: And, there's a lot of pressure on me. I'm here with you.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I know. I know... Mills steps towards the open air entrance. He's watching something. The strange man is still heard offscreen. Tracy reaches to a high wooden shelf, trying to reach a b rice, her back to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I'm not going to close my eyes and block everything out, David. I'm not going to act like you delivered us to some sort of paradise. I can't... She gets the rice and turns. Mills is not there. She sigh angry, looks around. She walks towards the entrance and s him -- http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: In front of the stand, Mills has run to the corner of the sidewalk to help a very old woman with a cane. The elderl woman smiles up at Mills, takes his arm as he helps her o curb and across the street. He talks to her as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy's anger fades. She shakes her head, touched, amazed the plain boy scoutishness of her husband.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: Mills deposits the old woman on the other side. She thank patting him on the cheek. Mills starts back towards the f stand, proud of himself. A car screeches to a halt, just missing him. The driver leans out the window, yelling at Mills kicks the side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Fuck you. (as car leaves) Fuck you, you son of a bitch! I'm walking here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy rolls her eyes in amused disappointment. She sighs Mills passes the babbling strange man, comes up to Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I couldn't pass it up. I never had a chance to actually do that. But, we can start the argument right back up where we left off, right? Tracy looks at him, charmed, no longer willing to fight.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (playing dumb) What? Tracy wraps an arm around Mills and kisses him. He holds

dialogues.speaker: STRANGE MAN
dialogues.text: That was the theme from tv's Mod Squad. I'm surprised nobody got that one. The strange man starts humming a new tune. An old man tri get through the aisle where Mills and Tracy are kissing.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: (infuriated) Excuse me. Excuse me! http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small transistor RADIO PLAYS on the bedside table. Mills and Tracy are in bed, making love under the sheets. move rhythmically, kissing, sweating hard. Mills holds Tracy's hair in his hands, pulls her head bac she gasps and he thrusts his entire body against hers. Mills' hair is soaked. He is anything but mellow as a lov quickening while Tracy twists underneath him. Tracy holds to the back of his neck with one hand. Finally, Mills pushes himself up on his arms, holding his down against Tracy's chest. Holds for a long moment, till spent and lowers himself against her, into her arms. He r long time. She kisses his forehead, keeping her eyes clos Finally, Mills rolls off her, gets behind her and wraps t of them in the sheets. He folds himself against her, and stay that way.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Goodnight. After a long moment, Mills shifts back, sits up. Tracy lo over her shoulder at him as he takes a towel off a chair stands. Mills wraps the towel around his waist. He leans over to give Tracy a last kiss. She watches him the room. She is about to say something, but does not. A comes on in the other room, leaking through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills sits down at his desk. He starts looking through po paperwork. The RADIO in the other room goes OFF in mid so

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is cold, clean. Stainless steel. White tile. Man pathologists work at slabs. Mills and Somerset are with D SANTIAGO, 35, who stands over the mostly dissected obese

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO
dialogues.text: If you take a look here, buddies... http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ I can tell you, it was not a poison. If you can see... I have emptied all of everything out of the stomach. But, look at it, now that I took away the liver. Santiago reaches into the belly of the cavernous corpse. moves closer beside Somerset, but not too close, trying t his disgust. We hear squashy sounds as Santiago works, bu don't see in.

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I move the lungs over. First, see how big this fat son-of-a-bitch stomach is. Now... here is the strange thing, on the stomach. Stretches. (pointing) And, here is it distended. Look at the size of that, because of the foods.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I can see what you're pointing at...

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO
dialogues.text: On the stomach. The lines of distention. Somerset's looking in, not believing what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Doctor, are you saying this man... ate till he burst?

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO
dialogues.text: Yes, well, he didn't actually burst. He was bleeding, inside of himself. And, there's a hemotoma on the outside... on the belly. Somerset walks around the slab, looking the body over.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: He died by eating?

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO
dialogues.text: Someone punched him, or kicked him. Somerset notices something on the partially shaved head. He leans close to look at five or six small bruises on th of the dead man's head; circular bruises, some darker tha others, all about the same diameter as a dime.

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Oh, and there is this here... something else you have to look at and see. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset stands straight, realizes something about the br

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Most of his stomach contents are in the lab now... but, this. I found these in the fat man's stomach. Santiago looks amongst tools, buckets and jars of liquid. picks up a glass jar and shows it to Mills. In the jar: m little bits of blue plastic. Like scrapings.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Plastic? Mills gets Somerset's attention, hands him the jar. Somer looks at it a long time.

dialogues.speaker: SANTIAGO
dialogues.text: Why these were in a fat man's stomach, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the door to the murder scene, Mills and Somerset through the RESTRICTED AREA/CRIME SCENE seal.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Those bruises on the back of the victim's head were caused by the muzzle of a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: So, the killer had him at gunpoint, and gave him a choice: eat, or get your head blown off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset and Mills enter. Somerset takes out the jar of p scrapings, turns on the now normal light. They begin to s

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: He was force-fed... till his body started rejecting the food. He literally couldn't eat another bite.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: So, the killer held a bucket under him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: His throat was swollen from the effort. He was bleeding internally. He must have blacked out... and, if you're the killer, you're not going to want to wait around for him to die. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset examines the counter tops and wall. Mills gets d his knees, examines the linoleum floor.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You kick him, pop him like a fucking balloon. (touches floor) Somerset, look here. Somerset gets down, holds the jar against the linoleum.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Same color and texture. They both crawl on hands and knees, study every inch of f

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: If this is what that is... it doesn't make sense. It doesn't figure.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Always look for one thing to focus on. There's always one singular thing, and it might be as small as a speck of dust, but find it and focus... till it's an exhausted possibility.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: How are pieces of the floor going to get in the guy's stomach?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Exactly. Why would so many pieces be inside his stomach unless they were placed there intentionally? Somerset notices deep scratches in the linoleum, fingers grooves. He takes a piece of plastic from the jar, holds the scratches, fiddles with it, fits it in. He looks up t these scratches are in front of the refrigerator. It look they were caused by the refrigerator having been pulled a from the wall and pushed back at some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are BEHIND THE REFRIGERATOR as it is rocked back and f It's pulled away from the wall. Somerset and Mills strain a few more feet, then release. They lean to look -- The refrigerator had hidden a space on the wall where the has been cleared. In that space: a circle, smeared in gre and a note taped in the center of the circle. Somerset's BEEPER starts BEEPING. Mills leans to read:

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: "Dear Detectives. Long is the way, and http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ hard, that out of hell leads up to the light." (looks at Somerset) This is not good.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Milton.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It's a quote from a book. Milton's Paradise Lost. Somerset takes out his beeper, looks at the LED window. H looks up at Mills, like they've received very bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A marble hallway. A DETECTIVE, 50, nervously chewing his quickly leads Mills and Somerset past cops and forensics.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: I said to myself, I'm not going to screw around with this. Nope. Fuck that. It's still pretty fresh meat. I called the medical examiner... he's coming. (stops at door) When I got to it, I knew. As soon as I laid eyes on it, I knew... The detective opens the door. FOLLOW Somerset and Mills -

dialogues.text: Gross, deep yellow light comes through the only window wi blinds up. The light anoints a NUDE MAN displayed, dead.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...this is your guy who did this. The nude dead man's legs are folded under him as if he we kneeling, and he's bent forward, chin on the floor. His e are open, his arms outstretched before him. Mills and Som walk to either side of the man. The detective closes the door, bites his thumbnail. The apartment is on a high floor, so it's quiet. Somerset sees the window has been covered with a sheet of gel, stapled in place to produce the colored light. Mills examines the corpse. There's a chair one foot behin nude man. It's an elegant leather chair, drenched in bloo There's a carving knife on the carpet in the middle of a http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ stain of blood under the chair. Mills looks at pieces of rope on the floor behind the chair. The rope is knotted. Somerset crouches beside the body. There's a big piece of missing from the man's left side, as if the love-handle h lopped off. Hundreds of pennies lie scattered under and a the man. The man's hands are palms up, fingers wrapped ar more pennies. Mills walks over to examine a scale on the floor between corpse and the doorway. It's an old-fashioned counter-bal scale with two suspended dishes on a see-saw arm. In the dish: the hunk of flesh missing from the man's side. In t dish: a one pound counterweight.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) A pound of flesh. Somerset stands and walks backwards to view the entire sc from near the door. He looks worried, vaguely frightened. He turns his head, to a far wall. Beside a big, abstract, constructivist pai there's a note pinned up inside a triangular smear of blo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An office full of pictures, books and mugsheets, yet it i meticulously well kept. The CAPTAIN, 50, sits at his tidy He's dressed conservatively. Mills and Somerset sit befor Somerset reads from a photocopy of the note they just fou

dialogues.text: (reading) "One pound of flesh, no more no less. No cartilage, no bone, but only flesh. This task done, and he would go free." The captain is a calm man, but whenever not speaking, wit fail, he clenches his jaw repeatedly, causing the muscles neck and jaw to pulse. Somerset stands, paces.

There's a gun to your head... but, what part or parts of your body are expendable? Mills sits back in his chair, arms crossed, seems anxious doesn't know why they're here. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.text: Mr. Gold tried for the whole pound at once, his love handle. But, he went into shock. Bled to death.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: What is the point, Somerset?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Look at both killings together. This murderer is an artist.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: An artist?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: He uses colors and symbols. He positions the bodies after death, so he's working with composition. It's been premeditated so meticulously... and this is just the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Wrong. For all we know, we might never hear from him again, and I don't want that kind of talk floating around. Somerset shakes his head "no.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: The rats and the pennies. The circle and the triangle on the wall. There's something about them... these murders mean something.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: So? What? Somerset has no answer. The captain is irked, jaw clenchi

dialogues.text: This is his stuff, captain. I've been out in the cold most of the day.

dialogues.text: (to Somerset) Always working overtime up in that big brain of yours, huh? Always cooking.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I need you to know... I want us reassigned. We're declining this case. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.text: (sits up, angry) What?!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: This cannot be my last duty here. It's going to go on and on.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: You've left unfinished business before.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Everything else was taken as close to a conclusion as humanly possible.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Can I just say something?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Also... I don't think this should be Mills' first case.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: This is not my first case, fuckhead!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I don't have anyone else to give this to, Somerset. And nobody's going to swap with you.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Give it to me, then. There's nothing that says I have to fly with him. The captain considers this.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: If Somerset wants out, fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It would be too much for him, too soon.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (to captain) Could we talk about this in private? The captain looks at Somerset, then at Mills.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: That's not necessary. You're in.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 28 of 138  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Start picking up the pieces. I'll shuffle some paper and try to get you a new partner. Mills stands. Somerset will not look him in the eye. Mill leaves, slams the door. Somerset seems deflated.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You win, Somerset. You're out.

Headline: "GIVE POUND OF FLESH," SAYS BLOODTHRISTY KILLER, in big, red le The vendor places a third pile beside the others: SICKENI

dialogues.text: Old office. Moving boxes on the floor. The single window a billboard. Somerset works on a manual typewriter. He ty hunt-and-peck, slowly. His paperwork is on the desk in tw sloppy piles. A jarring SOUND is HEARD OFFSCREEN, like fi on a blackboard. Somerset looks up, irritated. A WORKMAN is working at the open door, holding the source sound, a razor blade he's using to scrape the words DETEC SOMERSET off the door's window.

dialogues.text: Sorry. Somerset turns back to typing. The captain steps in, look the workman, then drops more papers on Somerset's desk. As always, the neatly groomed captain clenches his jaw. H looks around. Two of boxes on the floor have DETECTIVE MI written across them. The captain picks one up, puts it on of the other. He sits, watching Somerset, starts straight the forms on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with yourself out there, Somerset?

dialogues.text: I'll get a job. Maybe on a farm. I'll http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 29 of 138  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker fix up my house.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Can't you feel it yet? (pause) Can't you feel that feeling... that you won't be special anymore?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (lying) I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: You know. Somerset reclines, looks at the captain.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Did you read in the paper today, about the man who took his dog for a walk? And how he was mugged? And, his wallet was taken, and his watch. Then, while he was still lying unconscious, his attacker stabbed him with a knife in both eyes. It happened last night. Not far from here.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I heard.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I have no understanding of this place.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: It's always been like this. Somerset saddles up to the typewriter. Hunt-and-peck.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Yes. You're absolutely right. The captain lays the paperwork down in two neat stacks.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: You were made for this work, Somerset. I can't believe you're going to trade it all in for a tool belt and a fishing rod. But, I guess I'm wrong. The captain leaves. Somerset looks up now that the captai gone. He grabs the paper piles and ruffles them back to t disheveled state. He looks at the workman. The workman is looking at Somerset, has a rag in his hand remove the last remnants of Somerset's name.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 30 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ (angrily) Put a little elbow grease into it! The workman is startled, continues his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandly furnished apartment where the second murder t place has been dusted for prints and searched. Two female forensics are at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is seated in front of a long writing desk with many drawers. All the drawers are open. Mills looks through le and stationary. Nothing of use. He tosses the pile back. He sits back, frustrated, yanks off one rubber glove, loo around the room. Books have been taken off their shelves, bed has been stripped. The room has been given the once o The victim's family photographs hang in expensive frames wall. There are at least thirty photos of various sizes: ancestors, sons and daughters, grandchildren and friends. over-weight forensic, CHRIS, 35, leans in through the doo Mills looks up and Chris shakes his head glumly.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: He must have left us another puzzle to solve... somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We'll keep looking, but we're running out of possibilities. Chris leaves and Mills stands to stretch. Something catch Mills' eye. He walks over to the door, curious. At the ba the open door, there's a ball of paper wedged under to ac doorjamb. Mills puts his glove back on, pulls the ball ou He uncrumples the paper as the door slowly swings shut. T page has a drawing on it, of the sun with waves of heat a edges. There is a single eye in the center of the sun. An arrow is drawn in dried blood on the back of the closi door. Mills notices this and pushes the door closed. The blood arrow points to the side and up, seems to be po to the photo gallery wall. Mills goes to examine the phot His eyes search each photo... one by one... till he sees

Under the glass, on the photo itself, circles have been drawn in blood around the woman's eyes.

dialogues.text: An assault on the senses. Crowded streets and sidewalks. every corner, in every doorway, on every stairwell -- fre junkies, punks, leather boys and motorcycle girls. A few tourists wander in the mix, heedful of the dangers around Buildings border narrowly. Somerset walks against the stream. He carries a file. CAR HORNS HOWL. MUSIC BLASTS from the entrances of clubs. REGGAE from one club is soon OVERTAKEN by RAP from a seco story window. TECHNO-POP blasts from the tattoo parlor. Somerset does not like this place, views it with disdain. walks to avoid two men fighting on the ground. The men ar pulling hair and pounding each other idiotically. Somerset takes a cigarette from a full pack, lights it as crosses through the traffic jam in the street. A VAGRANT up with his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: VAGRANT
dialogues.text: Spare me a cigarette, money-grip? Spare me a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Sorry. Last one. He walks on. We BEGIN to HEAR JAZZ MUSIC.

dialogues.text: A club at capacity. The JAZZ MUSIC CONTINUES like a slow, breeze from a JAZZ TRIO on a platform. The air is thick with smoke. Yuppies sit elbow to elbow w the last members of the beat generation. Everyone's drink beer, smoking pot. Somerset crosses the club, looking for someone. He takes tissue from his pocket, rips pieces off and jams the piec his ears. At the back of the club, a major-league bouncer stands in front of a closed door. Somerset shows his badg the bouncer steps aside with reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are black. Somerset opens the door, enters, wal down the long flight of stairs. As Somerset descends, the MUSIC FADES and is ENGULFED by the sound of SPEED METAL. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ DEAFENING. At the bottom, Somerset opens another door. He enters --

Mills points the remote, turns the t.v. off as reporters Talbot. Mills stares at the blank screen, dispirited. Across the room, Tracy stands in the doorway. Mills does see her. He looks at the photocopy and sits at his desk. Tracy watches him, great concern in her sad eyes.

dialogues.text: Mills and Somerset walk onto the roof. It is a spectacula on all sides. Miles of city lights. Breathtaking. SOUNDS the CITY reach them.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No connection between the two victims? Mills shakes his head, unloads what he's holding onto a r table. He sits in one of two lawn chairs. Somerset sits a from him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: No witnesses of any kind?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: None. Which I can't understand. It's like this guy's invisible.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: In this city, minding your own business is a perfected science. Somerset takes a picture from the file, the drawing of th with an eye at its center. He opens a book, CHRISTIAN SYM which is full of illustrations. He starts paging through.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: At the precinct, Sunday nights, they offer a public crime prevention course. And, the very first thing they teach is that you should never scream "help" if you're in trouble. Scream "fire." Because people don't want to get caught up in anything. But, a fire... that's entertainment. They come running. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset holds the books up to Mills, points to a picture sun and eye, same as the drawing Mills found.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: "The Sun in Splendor with the Eye." It refers to God the father, and to Saint Thomas Aquinas.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Which saint is he?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Aquinas wrote a summary of theology, Summa Theologica. And he wrote about the seven deadly sins. Mills takes the book and looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Now, what else have you got?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Look, I appreciate being able to talk this out, but... it's my case.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: So... satisfying my curiosity. I'm still leaving town on Sunday. Mills is pondering, very tired. He unlatches his briefcas takes a photocopy of the photo of the falsely pretty woma hands it to Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: The eyes were circled. With Mr. Gold's blood.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: This is his wife?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (nods) She was away on business. She got back the day he was killed. If this means she saw anything, I don't know what. We've questioned her about ten times.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: And, if it's a threat?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: We put her in a safe house.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: This is the one thing. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two twenty-story tenement buildings stand practically und the span of a bridge. The streets are littered with garba Teenagers stand in cliques in front of a liquor store. Ca pass slowly, CAR STEREOS PUMPING out HIP HOP. Under the bridge, in shadow, a car is parked between two dumpsters. The trunk is open.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE CAR
dialogues.text: The trunk is full of cardboard boxes which are in turn fu tall, orange candles. Hundreds of candles. JOHN leans in the trunk's bulb, opens a leather pouch and checks the co A plastic bottle of prescription pills. A bottle of aspir hypodermic needle filled with liquid. Lastly, many jars o food: STRAINED CARROTS, STRAINED SPINACH, CREAMED CORN, e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John climbs the stairs holding the leather case and a clo shoebox. He wears clip-on sunglasses, a hat pulled low, a overcoat on his plump body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John comes from the stairwell door, looks, walks up the h The walls are graffitied. The soiled floor is wet in spot ARGUMENTS and LOUD CHILDREN are HEARD from behind closed John comes to apartment 303. He's winded from the climb. takes out keys, lets himself in. Closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset stands at the edge, holding the photo of Mrs. Go puffs on a cigarette, looks out at the city lights.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It's like he's preaching. (pause) The sins were used in medieval sermons. There were seven cardinal virtues, and then seven deadly sins, as a learning tool. The sins distract man from true worship. True faith. Mills is seated at the table with art books open. A breeze fans the pages of the books. The flipping pages views of heaven, hell, adoration, crucifixion and sin. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 51 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Like in these paintings, and in Dante's Purgatory, right? But, in Purgatory, Dante and his buddy climb that big mountain...

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Seven Terraces of Purgation.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Anyway... pride comes first, not gluttony. And in all the paintings, the sins are in a different order. I can't find a pattern.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Because there's creativity in the mix. Consider these books as the murderer's inspiration. Or aspiration. Somerset drops his cigarette to the empty street, watchin glowing tip fall. He looks at the woman's circled eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: He sees himself contributing to the body of Christian work.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: He's punishing these people.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: For all of us to see and learn from. These murders are like forced attrition.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What? Forced what?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Attrition. When you regret your sins, but not because you love God.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Because someone's holding a gun on you. Somerset thinks. He walks from the edge to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: When Mr. Gold's wife found the body, about how long was she in the apartment?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: She didn't find it. The door to the apartment was open and a neighbor...

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I thought you said she found the body. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker When she got back from a business trip.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: No. She got back after you and I had already been there. Somerset thinks, coming up with something.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: What? Somerset holds up the photo of Mrs. Gold.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Maybe she is supposed to see something... she just hasn't had a chance to see it yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is like a bland hotel room. Mills stands beside GOLD. He shows her photos from the murder scene. Mrs. Gol crying. Somerset stands across the room.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Please, look for anything strange or out of place. Anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: I... I don't understand. Why now? Mills helps her go through the photos. He is shaken himse not wanting to put her through this.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I need your help if we're going to get the guy who killed your husband. If there's anything in these pictures... Mrs. Gold sobs quietly, wipes her tears.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: I don't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely sure?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: I can't do this now... please. ette to the empty street, watching the glowing tip fall. He looks at the woman's circled eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: He sees himself contributing to the body of Christian work. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|

dialogues.text: He's punishing these people.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: For all of us to see and learn from. These murders are like forced attrition.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What? Forced what?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Attrition. When you regret your sins, but not because you love God.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Because someone's holding a gun on you. Somerset thinks. He walks from the edge to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS

dialogues.text: I thought you said she found the body. When she got back from a business trip.

dialogues.text: No. She got back after you and I had already been there. Somerset thinks, coming up with something.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Please, look for anything strange or out http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ of place. Anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: I... I don't understand. Why now? Mills helps her go through the photos. He is shaken himse not wanting to put her through this.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I need your help if we're going to get the guy who killed your husband. If there's anything in these pictures... Mrs. Gold sobs quietly, wipes her tears.
