dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely sure?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: I can't do this now... please. Mills looks at Somerset. Somerset holds other photos.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: We have to show her those. There might be something she's missing. Somerset looks at the photos in his hand, hesitant. These photos show Mr. Gold's corpse, not covered in any way.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Have her look one last time.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: Wait. Here... here's something...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What is it? Mrs. Gold points at the constructivist painting on the wa one photo. The painting is an abstraction of colored squa

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: This painting... in the living room...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GOLD
dialogues.text: Why is it hanging upside-down? Mills jerks his head to look at Somerset. Big score. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where the greed murder took place. Somerset and M are taking the constructivist painting off the wall. Noth the wall behind the painting. Blank space.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: This has got to be it. Somerset puts the painting down, resting it on its bottom The frame is backed by a thick sheet of brown paper. He p to where the wire used to be screwed into the frame, and where it has been re-screwed.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It has to be. He changed the wire to rehang it. Somerset tears along the edge of the brown paper to get t space between it and the canvas. He tears out the entire Mills helps pull it away, but there's nothing there. Empt Mills looks at both sides of the paper, then tosses it aw

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It's nothing. Somerset pays the painting down, face up. He pokes his fi on the painted surface. Mills watches as Somerset kneels, out a credit card and presses it's edge against the canva trying to peel up some of the paint.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Give it up. The killer didn't paint the fucking thing. Somerset pushes the painting away, stands, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: He fucked us. Somerset backs away from the wall, staring at the space w the painting hung. There is only a nail. He stares intent then turns and walks out of the room. Mills holds his hands to his temples, furious. SOMERSET c HEARD from the other room, going through drawers, droppin things. GLASS is HEARD BREAKING. Mills grabs a lamp and t it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! Somerset comes back in, holding something. He steps over lamp and goes to the blank wall space. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Bear with me. Mills watches. Somerset has a woman's make-up compact in He opens it, uses the soft brush to begin applying the re powder to the wall around the nail.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Oh, yeah, sure. You got to be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Shut up and wait! Somerset brushes with wider strokes. He blows, leans very to the wall to study the powder. Leans closer still. Paus

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Call the print lab. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy is asleep with lights on. She stirs, opens her eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy opens the door, enters. It's quiet. She sees Mills Somerset are gone. She's all alone. Unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, we can see into the bedroom. Tracy co back from the living room. She goes to her side of the be kneels. She reaches between the mattress and bedspring, t out a paperback book she has hidden there. She comes to the window, opens it and climbs out onto the escape. She sits, dangles her feet through the metal bars opens the book and tries to read by the street light, res her head against the railing. A WOMAN is HEARD SCREAMING distantly. Tracy looks down the empty street, unsettled. The woman i heard again. Tracy lays back, looks at the sky, holding herself. We ca see the title of the book: PREPARING FOR PARENTHOOD. Ther picture of a baby on the cover. Tracy cries, quietly. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MALE FORENSIC uses a magnifying glass to study a very c fingerprint in black powder on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSIC
dialogues.text: Oh, boy...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Talk to me. The forensic bites his lip, still studying. Mills and Somerset watch the forensic who works offscreen

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) Listen, honestly have you ever seen anything like this? Been involved in anything remotely like this?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No. I have not.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSIC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, I can tell you this, detectives... The forensic steps down from a stool. Behind him, where t painting once was, there are fingerprints, clear and dist The prints have been left side by side, to form letters w form the words: HELP ME.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSIC, (CONT)
dialogues.text: ...just by studying the underloop... these are not the victim's prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. A TECHNICIAN sits before an old computer. The compu green screen shows fingerprints being aligned, compared a rejected; whir - click - whir - click - whir - click. Mil Somerset watch, bathed in the green glow.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It doesn't work for me. I can't believe he wants us to help him stop.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Who the hell knows? There's plenty of schizoids out there doing dirty deeds they don't want to do. With tiny voices whispering nasty things in their ears. Somerset doesn't buy it. The technician adjusts a knob.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker I've seen this baby take three days to finish a cycle, so you guys can go cross your fingers somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset and Mills come from the print lab. A janitor is mopping the hall. Somerset onwards. door. Mills flops beside him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You really meant what you said to Mrs. Gold. You really believe we'll get him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: And you don't?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I wish I still thought like you. I'm so far gone from that.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: So, tell me what you think we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: All we do is pick up the pieces. We take all the evidence... all the pictures, statements. Write everything down and note what time things happened. We take it all, make a nice, neat pile and file it away. Just in case it's ever needed in a courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You're unbelievable. In my entire life, you're the oldest man I've ever met.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I've seen even the most promising clues lead to dead ends. Hundreds of times.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I've seen the same. I'm not the country hick-boy you seem to think I am. Somerset takes out a cigarette and lights it. Mills slumps back, crosses his arms, closes his eyes to s

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: In this city, if all the skeletons came out of all the closets... if every un- revenged corpse were to suddenly rise and walk again, there would be no more room for the living. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| The computer is HEARD WHIRRING AND CLICKING sits with a groan on a couch outside the
Page 59 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Don't try to tell me you didn't get that rush tonight... that adrenalin. Like we were getting somewhere. (pause) And, don't try to tell me it was because you thought we found something that would play well in a courtroom. Somerset looks at Mills, puffs the cigarette. The compute heard: whir - click - whir - click...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our detectives are fast asleep on the couch, leaning agai each other. People pass and look at them strangely.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Wake up, Glimmer Twins. We have a winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A windowless classroom. The captain stands in front with white screen at his side. The face of a black man, 25, ZE projected on the screen from a slide projector.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: His street name is Zero, as some of you know. His prints were found at the scene by Detectives Mills and Somerset. FIVE hardened POLICE OFFICERS, four men, one woman, sit i chairs facing the captain. They all wear bullet-proof ves with "POLICE" stencil-painted across them. Somerset and M sit in back, drinking coffee, still trying to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Now, Zero has a long, long history of mental illness. Serious illness. He was all over your television sets two years ago after he raped and killed a seventy-three year old woman. He got off, as the saying goes, ona technicality. So we watched him on the streets, and he went out of circulation about a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE COP
dialogues.text: If he disappeared, what do you want from us? http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: His last place of residence is still in his name. A search warrant is being pushed through the court as we speak. A red-headed cop, CALIFORNIA, 28, raises his meaty hand.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: So, have the housing cops walk up and ring the doorbell. Problem solved. The cops laugh. The captain clenches his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Listen, California. When you go in, if Zero isn't home, some of his buddies might be house-sitting. And besides using, Zero deals, so, you will be very uninvited guests. There is chatter among the cops. Somerset leans to Mills the captain continues the briefing.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Does not seem like our killer, does it?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You tell me. I'm new in town.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Zero does possess the requisite degree of insanity... but, he doesn't have the desire somehow. Our killer seems to have more purpose. More purpose than Zero could ever conceive of.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: We'll tag along. Somerset wants no part of that.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Why would we?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Satisfy our curiosity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills drives, follows a police van. Somerset rides shotgu Mills is pumped, ready. Somerset takes one Rolaids tablet fresh roll and chews it.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You ever take one? http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 61 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset pulls out his gun, checks the load.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No. Never in twenty-four years. I took my gun out only five times with the actual intention of using it. I never fired it. Not once.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I pulled it once, fired it once. I never took a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: And? Mills turns a corner, tires screeching.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It was my first one of these. We were a secondary unit, in vice. I was pretty shaky going in. When we busted the door, looking for a junkie, the fucking guy opened fire. One cop was hit in the arm. He went flying... like in slow motion. (pause) I remember riding in the ambulance. His arm was like... a piece of meat. I thought, it's just his arm. But, he bled to death right there anyway. A pause. Somerset opens the window, feels the air on his

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: How did the fire-fight end?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Well, I was doing really good in Philly up till then. Lots of simple busts. I've always had this weird luck... but, this was wild. (pause) I got that fuck with one shot... right between the eyes. And the next week, the mayor's pinning a medal on me. Picture in the paper, the whole nine yards.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I expected it to be bad, because I heard about other guys. You know... I took a human life. But, I slept like a baby that night. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset eats another antacid.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I think Hemingway wrote somewhere... I can't remember where, but he wrote that, in order to live in a city, you have to have the ability to kill. I think he meant you truly must be able to do it, not just faking it, to survive.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Sounds like he knew what he was talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack vials and hypodermic needles crunch under heavy boo The five cops from the briefing, fully geared up, rifles handguns held, move quickly up the stairs, single-file. Somerset and Mills follow, guns out. Somerset is sweating bullets. Mills is juiced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops enter the dank hallway, the same hall we saw Joh before. They move cautiously, stepping over a drunken, he man. A door opens and a woman peeks out. The female cop p her gun and the woman obeys, slamming the door. California leads, steps up to apartment 303. He has a sea warrant scotch-taped to the front of his bullet-proof ves

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: (to black cop) This is it. Give it up. A black cop hoists a battering ram. The other cops get on sides of the door. Mills moves front. Somerset hangs back

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Police!! Open the door! The black cop brings the ram forward with a splintering t The door flies open. The cops storm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops charge down a short hall into this incredibly du room. A bed sits against a far wall. Mills and California up to the bed. Someone lies under an indigo blanket. Thre other cops move, training their weapons on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sweetheart! http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ A blond cop goes into another room. Mills kicks the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Get up now, motherfucker! Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blond cop enters, gun trained, looks around in confus The room's tables, chairs and floor are covered with hund colorful, plastic air fresheners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset moves in, looks around. He notices the area arou bed, the ceiling, walls and floor, has been painted indig while the rest of the room is its original white. On a wa white sheet is pinned up with a square drawn on it in exc

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I said get up, Sleepyhead! Mills pulls the indigo blanket off the bed, reveals the shriveled, sore-covered form of a black man who is blindf and tied to the bed with a thin wire wrapped time and tim around the bed. Tubes lead from the stained loincloth aro the man's waist and snake under the bed. The victim is partially covered by what seem to be piles of black spagh

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck me! Somerset pushes past the cops who recoil from the stench.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Sloth... it's sloth. The black cop touches the black spaghetti. Holds a piece.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK COP
dialogues.text: What the hell... those are dead worms.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) Check this out, dick. California points with his gun to the end of the black ma right arm. The hand is gone, severed at the wrist long ag

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It's him. It's Zero.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker Someone call an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Someone call a hearse, more like. The female cop has gone to the wall where the sheet is pi up. She pulls the sheet aside and finds: fifty-two polaro pictures; all pictures of Zero tied to the bed, with a da written at the bottom of each. it is a visual history of physical decay. The blond cop enters from the other room.

dialogues.speaker: BLOND COP
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Hey, California. Get your people out. Somerset takes out rubber gloves and puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: You heard him. Hit the hall, and don't touch anything. The other cops file out as Mills goes to examine the pola under the sheet. Somerset replaces the sheet over Zero's California stays by his side.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It looks like he's some kind of friggin' wax sculpture. Somerset places his finger along Zero's throat.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Somerset, you... you better look here. Mills studies the polaroids. Somerset walks to join him.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: All pictures of Zero tied to the bed. (crouches) The last one's dated three days ago. Somerset looks at the first photo. In it, Zero is bound a gagged, but he is fit, healthy.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (awed) The first photo... it's dated one year ago. Almost to the day. California lifts Zero's blanket to peek under, examining morbid curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Mo-ther... http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 65 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Mills kneels and lifts the bottom of the sheet off the fl finds an open shoebox. On the box: TO THE DETECTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What's this? California leans close to Zero's gaunt, blindfolded face.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: You got what you deserved, Zero. Somerset leans down beside Mills. Mills looks through the shoebox. Inside are plastic, zip-lock bags. One bag conta small clumps of hair, one contains a yellow liquid...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: A urine sample... hair sample... fingernail clippings. He's laughing at us. California is still close to Zero's face when suddenly Ze lips twist. Zero lets out a loud, guttural bark. Californ jerks back in fear, shouting, falling over a chair. Mills and Somerset reel, standing. They see California on ground, scared out of his mind, pointing.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: He's alive! Mills and Somerset look towards the bed. Zero's lips move feebly as he lets out a sick, gurgling m

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: He's still alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd has gathered. Mills' car, the police van and two ambulances are parked on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siege cops are in the hall, holding neighbors at bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three ambulance attendants are at the bed, working on Zer attendant uses wire-cutters to clip Zero's bonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Somerset stand in the middle of one flight of s They are both highly agitated. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: The way this has gone, I didn't think it was possible, but we may have underestimated this guy. The type of intestinal fortitude it must take... to keep a man bound for a full year. To sever his hand and use it to plant fingerprints.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I want him bad. I don't just want to catch him anymore. I want to hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Listen... we have to divorce ourselves from our emotions here. We have to keep focusing on the small details.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I don't know about you, Somerset, but I feed off my emotions.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: He'll string us along all the way if we're not careful. Mills is looking at the floor, burning with anger. Somers grabs him by the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me?! Mills pushes Somerset's hand off.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I hear you. There is a sudden brilliant flash of light and the SOUND CAMERA ADVANCING. Mills and Somerset look -- Down the stairs, John is posing as a reporter. He has his camera and flash up, pointed at the detectives.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Say cheese. He takes another picture, flashbulb flashing. Mills charg downwards, grabs John by his wrinkled clothing.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing? John squirms, holds up a laminated PRESS identification p

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I have a right, Officer. I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Mills shoves him and John stumbles a few steps, then fall the landing below with a thud. His glasses fly off.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean anything. This is a closed crime scene now! Somerset steps down and pulls Mills back. John stands.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You can't do this! You can't...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here! John gets his glasses, scrambles downstairs, out of sight

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The public has a right to know! Somerset yanks Mills harder, till Mills sits on the stair

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: How do those cockroaches get here so quick?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: They pay cops for the inside scoop, and they pay well. You can hate them, but you better give them something, or they'll make it all up.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (calming) I'm sorry... I just...

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Oh, it's alright. It's always impressive to see a man feeding off his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills stands with the blase DR. BEARDSLEY, who reviews a chart on a clipboard. Zero lies inside an oxygen tent wit tubes running into him. The room is dark.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDSLEY
dialogues.text: A year of immobility seems about right, judging by the deterioration of the muscles and spinal cord. Blood tests show a whole smorgasbord of drugs in his system. Heroin... crack even an antibiotic which was administered to keep the bed sores from infecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Mills looks into the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: He hasn't said anything, or tried to express himself in any way?

dialogues.speaker: BEARDSLEY
dialogues.text: Even if his brain were not mush, which it is... he chewed his own tongue off a long time ago. Mills winces, moves away from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: There's no way he'll survive?

dialogues.speaker: BEARDSLEY
dialogues.text: Detective, he'd die right now of shock if you were to shine a flashlight in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall church on a bustling street. Smoggy air has eaten stonework. The homeless are camped out on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest's accommodations are quite spacious and comfor The parish's wealth is evident. FATHER BLEEKER, 38, stand looking at several 8" by 10" glossies. He's dressed in hi "civilian" clothing, wears his hair short and proper. The photos are making him heartsick. Bleeker hands them to Somerset who is seated by a firepla

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: Put them away. I wish you hadn't brought them into the church.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I needed for you to see them. Father Bleeker shakes his head, as if he were trying to f the images. Somerset replaces the murder photos in a file

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: There were five principal phases in the development of early Christian art. From Hellenistic through the Renaissance... each period was affected by the decrees of religious leaders.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: If this killer belongs to a certain branch of the church... if he collects http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ religious art from a certain period, I want to know. I have to narrow it down. Bleeker walks to an ornate, gold cabinet. He puts on a pa cotton gloves.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: The influences on these... things he's done, couldn't have come before the Gothic period. What's in those pictures is presented far too asymmetrically. Bleeker crosses himself before using a key to open the ca He takes out an ancient devotional book and a piece of cl

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER, (CONT)
dialogues.text: The colors will tell the tale. Bleeker takes the book to a table. Somerset follows. Blee lays the cloth under the book, opens the book, tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Each sin had a symbolic color. But the specific color designations changed throughout the ages. Somerset leans to examine Bleeker's illuminated manuscrip Two pages of prayer. The prose is elaborately formed, surrounded by colorful illustrations of the seven deadly Bleeker's finger points to a rendering of a man seated on rock, guzzling from a jug. It's been painted in orange.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER, (0.S.,CONT)
dialogues.text: This is an example. Gluttony is the sin, and the color is orange. This particular manuscript is preserved from the 18th century.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the murders, gluttony is green. Greed is yellow. Sloth is indigo. Bleeker steps away and Somerset gets closer to the pages.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: So, if this murderer is as precise as you say, then you need to find out at what period in history was gluttony green... and so on.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Where do I look? If the colors changed so often?

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: (contemplates) http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ There is one man... Father Stone. (pause) I haven't heard from him for quite some time. This was his passion. He spent his life studying the sins... and preaching against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chalkboard on the wall: 1 gluttony (x) 5 wrath 2 greed (x) 6 pride 3 sloth (x) 7 lust 4 envy Mills is behind his paperwork covered desk, listening to uniformed OFFICER who looks over a report sheet.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Zero's landlord said an envelope of cash was in the office mailbox each month. He says, quote, "I never heard a single complaint from this guy and nobody ever complained about him. He's the best tenant I ever had."

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: There's a landlord's dream tenant. A paralyzed man with no tongue.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Who pays his rent on time.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Bring me everything as soon as it's transcribed. The officer leaves. Mills starts sorting through piles on desk. He doesn't know where to begin. He sits back in his chair, looks at the collage-like coll of pictures pinned on the walls: photos and diagrams of t murder scenes, the drawing of the sun and eye, color page black and white copies of pages from art books. He stares, thinking. He stands, takes a photocopy off the The killer's first note: Dear Detectives, Long is the way, and hard, that out of hell leads up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (to himself) Milton. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big brass lamps hang from the high ceiling. Mahogany chai tables run down the center floor which is bordered by thr levels of balconies. People wander like ants in an ant fa Mills walks, taking it all in. He goes to the circulation Impatient patrons wait in a long line. He watches the bor HEAD LIBRARIAN, female, 64, help an old man at the desk. She opens the old man's books, runs a laser pen over a ba sticker, pushes a few buttons on a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the balcony railing, overlooking the main floor, Mil before a computer card catalog. He reads the computer scr unsure. He sets down his pad and pencil, cracks his knuck begins typing on the keyboard. The computer gives off a q BEEP. Pleased, Mills reads the screen. Types. On the screen: TITLE / PARADISE LOST_ He hits return. Reads the screen as information on the bo appears. He copies it on his pad, puts the pencil in his He types. On the screen: SUBJECT / JACK THE RIPPER_ Hits return. Again, he copies info from the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A monk opens a formidable gateway door, letting Father Bl and Somerset into a garden courtyard. Bleeker now wears h priestly garb and collar. The monastery's main building l at the end of a pathway. The building is stately, ivy-cov

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: Father Stone had a church and congregation of his own. But, he... there were some problems. The church is deserted now.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Problems? Bleeker continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls of the hallway are carved with images of saints Bleeker whispers to Somerset beside a windowless door. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: There was a small orphanage attached to the church, overseen by Father Stone. This was almost thirty years ago. (hesitant) He was an excellent priest, devoted in every way. Many in his parish demanded his return.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened. Bleeker sees a NUN down the hall, coming towards them.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: Allegations were made... Stone was accused of abusing the children in his care. But, those charges were never substantiated.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: What abuse?

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: It was claimed... that the children were beaten. And, punished severely. The nun is too close for Bleeker to speak freely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is unlocked and opened by the nun. Somerset ente Bleeker waits outside as the nun closes the door. It's da FATHER STONE, 73, is in a wheelchair. Feeble and frail, e sunken in their sockets. He looks up at Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Father Stone. I'ma policeman. I'd like to ask you a few questions, if it's alright? The whites of Stone's eyes have yellowed. He seems to nod Somerset sits on a stool, close.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I want to ask you about the seven deadly sins.

dialogues.speaker: STONE
dialogues.text: The sins.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Yes, father. Stone reaches out a hand to touch Somerset's face. Stone' extremely long fingernails trail against Somerset's cheek http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 73 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset tries to hide his revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: STONE
dialogues.text: Are you one of mine?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I don't...

dialogues.speaker: STONE
dialogues.text: Are you saved? Do you have God?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I... I need to ask about the sins. Do you understand what I'm saying? Stone takes his hand away, seems to be getting angry.

dialogues.speaker: STONE
dialogues.text: Are you a sinner? Stone's weak arms wheel him away, towards a corner.

dialogues.speaker: STONE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: There are sinners here. Even here. And, pain waits for them. Hell is hungry for them. Stone bites his lip, moaning, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: STONE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: They don't realize... they don't know. (pause) Fuck them all! Somerset is shocked by the strength and volume of Stone's voice. The nun goes to place a comforting hand on Stone's shoulder. Stone is beginning to cry.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) They shouldn't have let you disturb him. This shouldn't have been allowed.

dialogues.speaker: STONE
dialogues.text: Where are the children? (much louder) Where are the children?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a mahogany hallway lined with book-carts, we look TH big WINDOW into the head librarian's office. The elderly librarian is at a computer, chain-smoking, working the ke Mills alternates talking on the telephone and reading thi his pad to the librarian. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ We cannot hear them, but it's clear Mills is excited as h back and forth, hovering over the librarian, looking at h computer screen, making suggestions, then walking to moni dot-matrix printer which spews a waterfall of computer pa onto the floor. Back and forth goes Mills, carrying the p He closes the pad, puts it in his pocket. The librarian finishes typing, sits back, done. Mills han the phone, goes to put it on the librarian's desk, but th drags, knocks a pile of books off a table. The librarian is irritated, goes to pick up the books. Mi apologizing. He goes to watch the printer. He tears the l sheet's perforated edge, gathers the huge pile of printed off the floor. Prize in hand, Mills is so grateful he bends to give the woman a kiss on the cheek, but she pushes him away, now e more annoyed. Mills goes to leave, knocks over another pi books. Before he can assist, the angry librarian points t door. Mills obeys like a scolded child, exits. The librarian shakes her head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A once exemplary church, now boarded up, neglected. Gothi style, it stands with deserted brownstones and empty lots rubble as neighbors. Smokestacks spew smoke distantly. Ca and trucks drive by on a nearby elevated highway, but dow on the street it's a ghost town. There's a building attached to the rear of the church. Somerset's car is parked beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows are covered over. Somerset and Father Bleeker through. Somerset has a flashlight with a wide beam. The is empty except for broken, cob-web covered school desks few file cabinets. There are cracked blackboards on the w Rats skitter away from the light. Somerset opens a file cabinet drawer. It's empty. He walk a door, starts pulling at the rotting boards which seal i

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I'm just looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset pushes the door. He and Bleeker enter from the classroom into the far back corner of the church. Big chu http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Shafts of colored light needle through the holes in the p of wood and cloth that cover the broken stained glass win Somerset walks down the center aisle between deteriorated rats run. Pigeons flap about, dirt drifting off their win Somerset shines his flashlight forward to the rather barr altar. To the right, at the top of the altar stairs, ther stone statue of a saint with his arms outstretched, welco The life-size saint is covered in spider-webs. Tiny spide crawl across his eyes, which look down on Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: Saint Jerome Emiliani. The patron saint of orphans. Somerset shines the flashlight against the back altar wal revealing a wooden carving of Christ crucified.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Is this still the Lord's house?

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: And, even if Father Stone was guilty of everything... if he was hurting children here? It's still the Lord's house? Father Bleeker finds this talk insulting and offensive.

dialogues.speaker: BLEEKER
dialogues.text: You have no faith, Somerset? Have you given up on the church entirely?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No. (pause) That's not what I've given up on. Somerset notices two ends of a thick rope suspended from ceiling above the center of the altar. He looks up, follo the rope with the flashlight, when he notices something e His mouth drops. Bleeker looks, and is equally horrified. Above them, in the beam of light: seven large paintings o panels tilted forward at the curve of the ceiling above t altar. Seven ancient paintings; seven deadly sins. The beam of light moves to the panel to the immediate rig painting of a man kneeling, grasping at gold coins all ar him. The man is naked, as was the victim of the greed mur The chief color in this panel is a vulgar yellow. The third in the series is sloth. The painting, in indigo http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ shows a man at rest in a pliant bed. The skeletal man's e are rolled up in their sockets. He is covered in slimy wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are full of patrol cars. Cops and forensics e and exit the church from various doorways. Saw-horses are loaded off a flat-bed truck as a police barricade is erec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much activity, as forensics with flashlights go about the business, checking every nook and cranny of the church, l for any sign that someone's been here recently. Small tem floodlights are hoisted on tripods. Two photographers stand at the tops of tall ladders. Flas photo after flash-photo is taken of the seven paneled tab Near the open church doors, Mills speaks with great anima holding his ream of computer paper. Somerset looks at the and the tableau, preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Our guy's a bookworm, right? And, I know it's a long shot, but you have to give a picture id and current phone bill to get a library card. Hey... Mills snaps his fingers in Somerset's face, gets his atte

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I made two separate lists of books. One relating to the sins... Dante's Purgatory, Canterbury Tales... The Dictionary of Catholicism... all the religious stuff. The second list was books about torture methods, mass murderers... sadomasochism. Whatever our killer might study to do the things he's done. Whatever his other interests are. Somerset takes the computer list.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: So, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Alright. Everything at the library goes into a computer. So, you can get in the system and cross-reference... Mills fumbles in his pocket, takes out his pad and reads.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Let's say you take, Dante's Purgatory, call number eight-five-one-D, and... The Biography of the Marquis de Sade, ninety-two S-A-D-E. Put those books in the system, and the computer can give you the name of anyone who's ever taken out both those books. And, it doesn't just give you their name and address, it gives you a complete history of their library reading habits. Mills slaps the list in Somerset's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (psyched up) If somebody's out there reading Paradise Lost and studying The Life and Times of Charlie Manson, I want to talk to them. Somerset looks up from the list, warming to it. He starts looking around, searching for someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset and Mills exit down the stairs. Somerset's still searching, holding the list. He spies a uniformed cop, DA

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Dario! Come here. Dario runs up. Somerset puts his hand on his shoulder and him walk with him. Mills continues on to his car.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: According to the Father, this orphanage wasn't around for more than five or six years in the late fifties. So, I want someone to go to the Department of Child Welfare or City Hall and dig up all the records on this place. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: DARIO
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Get a list of every child who attended this orphanage before it shut down. Get it on my desk within the hour. Somerset releases Dario, who runs to obey. Somerset goes own car. Mills is driving to leave, stops, revs the engin Somerset hands the computer list through the window.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You thought of this all by yourself? This was your brainstorm? http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is that so hard for you to believe?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It's a pleasant surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'm not as stupid as I look. Mills peels away. Somerset heads to his own car.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (to himself) I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven large photos hang with the other materials on the w The seven tableau paintings. Gluttony, greed and sloth, followed by vanity. Vanity shows a woman standing in fron mirror, staring at her image. The floor around her is sca with flowers. The primary color is violet, and as in all paintings, there is a quality of ugliness in the characte

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ramirez. Manuel Ramirez.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No... I don't see any Ramirez. The lust painting is next. It shows a man standing over a woman. The woman is nude, under a sheet, and the man's fe are bizarre, lecherous. He wants that woman. There are ap on the floor and on the bed. The color is red.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Elinski. Dennis Elinski.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. Envy is particularly gruesome. The Devil is seen hovering the air, wearing a crown, his body orange and slick, wrap a cloak of flames. His arms held high, his right hand gri sword, a bolt of lightning, arrows, wheat, thistles, etc. left hand, holds a plain globe around which a serpent has wrapped itself. He looks down at several pitiful mortals pit of fire. The mortals reach for him, yearn for him, th on their bodies is stretched taut over their bones.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Atwater? Paul Atwater.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ No. Wrath shows a man surrounded by vaporous, satanic demons. stands in a puddle of blood, looking at his hands stained and dripping blood. Other than the rich red, the color is Mills is at his desk, a good portion of the print-out lis draped to the floor. He rubs his eyes, sighing, gets back it. Somerset, at the temporary desk, studies his orphan l

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Okay, here we go. Listen to the books this guy's been taking out... (reading list) Basic Homicide Investigation. Forensic Toxicology... The Encyclopedia of Modern Serial Killers... (looks up, excited) Of Human Bondage.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: That's not what you think it is. Mills is disappointed, runs his finger further down the p

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Somerset... (reading list) The Writings of Saint Thomas Aquinas. Mills points to the drawing of "the Sun in splendor with eye" which hangs on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Aquinas. Right?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: That's right. Let me have it. Mills looks at the page... searching...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Fuck... he used a false name.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: His library card lists him as Jonathan Doe. John Doe. Mills sits back, angry. Something strikes Somerset as odd Familiar. He starts leafing quickly through the orphanage

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: What? http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset finds what he's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Christ... it's like a sick joke.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: There is one boy here. He was abandoned... no one knew who his parents were, so he was named at the orphanage... (looks at Mills) John Doe. It's his legal name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset and Mills climb stairs, turn a corner into this

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It's impossible odds that this is him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: We're focusing.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I know, I know. On one little thing. I'm not complaining. I'11l follow anything we get and I'll take it any way we can get it.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: We'll look at him. Ask a few questions. Try to get a feeling whether we should keep tabs on him. They reach a door, apartment 3A. Somerset knocks. Mills t out his gun and looks at Somerset to ask "what do you thi Somerset nods that he should have the gun ready. Mills st the side of the door, knocks hard. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'll do the talking, right? Let me practice here... um, excuse me Mr. Doe, but, are you by any chance a serial killer? Oh... oh, you are? Well, come with us then, if you don't mind. Mills smiles at his own wit. A STAIR is HEARD CREAKING offscreen. Mills turns to look towards the stairs. A MALE FIGURE stands at the top of the stairs, wearing a standing in shadows. The man looks at them, lets out a sc of horror and reaches into his coat. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Somerset! GUNFIRE SOUNDS and a bullet slams into door 3A behind Mil and Somerset recoil in shock, going to the floor as anoth bullet explodes, blasting plaster off the wall. The man i HEARD RUNNING back down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It's him! Jesus Christ, we can get this fucker! Mills jumps up. He moves towards the railing. Somerset si and takes out his own gun. The stairwell is silent. Mills peers over the railing into the stairwell's center, pointed. A HEAVY METALLIC CLICK is HEARD. Echoes. Mills l backwards as bullets begin raining up from below, accompa the SOUND of an UZI SUB-MACHINE GUN FIRING. Somerset lays flat as he and Mills crawl away from the ra which is being shredded along with the floor around it. B soar unceasingly. Mills and Somerset hold their hands ove their ears. Pieces of wood and plaster fly everywhere. Th stops and the man can be HEARD RUNNING again. Mills gets up, covered in debris. He runs down into the s stairwell. Somerset rolls over, gets up more slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills rushes out into this weedy, overgrown courtyard. He a thin vagrant sleeping on the building's junk-pile, then all directions. His eyes are wild. His gun hand is shakin The courtyard is surrounded by alleyways. The shooter cou have gone anywhere and is nowhere in sight. Somerset come face wet with sweat. Mills holsters his gun.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think so. They look at each other for a long time. Both realizing t came very close to dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police cars on scene. Curious civilians have gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP THE STAIRWELL, several forensics are collecting shell casings, putting them in bags. The casings are scattered http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ the way up the stairs. ONE FORENSIC walks up beside a COP

dialogues.speaker: ONE FORENSIC
dialogues.text: I hear he's running around with an uzi in one hand and a book of poetry in the other.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: A real, modern-day renaissance man, huh? AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS, two forensics, SARAH and BILLY, behind Mills and Somerset. Surgical gloves on all hands. kicks at the door to apartment 3A with all his might. Aga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM -- door flies open. Mills enters with Somerset. Dark

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (to forensics) Give us first crack at it. Sarah and Billy wait in the hall. Somerset hits a switch wall and a lamp illuminates on a desk. The desk is in the center of the room, facing them. The walls, floor to ceil are covered with visual stimuli; pictures, paintings, new articles, sketches, writings on napkins and notebook shee etc. Mostly religious images. The far wall is made of shelves full of books. Mills goes the desk while Somerset goes to the books. Books: An Over of Theology, Handbook of Firearms, A History of the World Theologica, U.S. Criminal Law Review, etc. Mills looks at the desktop. The surface is marked by drie colors. There are tubes of paint laying out, boxes of wat colors and pastels. Mills looks at one corner of the desk orange candle has been allowed to burn down. The wax trai all the way down the edge of the desk to a puddle on the Somerset walks, studying one wall of pin-ups. There are articles about the seven deadly sins, pages from art book pencil drawings of Satan and Christ, and drawings of the paneled tableau paintings which inspired the murders. Som lifts several sheets to note the paper scraps are spaced tightly and completely that they cover the window. At the desk, Mills opens the top middle drawer. It's empt except for The Holy Bible. he opens another drawer, which filled with at least forty empty aspirin bottles. Somerset looks at a door which is papered over by all the newspaper articles and photographs about the seven deadly murders. He opens the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset enters. The ceiling light is on. There are bookshelves on each wall, filled with thousands of notebo Somerset takes one notebook down. It is a thick compositi book with a marbled black and white cover. Inside, the pa are covered in small handwritten sentences and drawings. Somerset takes down another notebook and opens it. Same a first; scribbled sentences and sketches. He walks to another wall, pulls another notebook. Same de

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills opens a final drawer to find a rosary and a revolve He looks around, nervous and excited, being in the murder lair. He goes to a closed door across the room, notices J Doe's bed in the corner. Sees Doe has a cross nailed to t ceiling directly above the bed's pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills enters the bathroom. It has been converted into a darkroom, lit by red bulbs, with strips of film hanging f ceiling. WATER is HEARD DRIPPING. Mills opens the shower curtain. Prints hang drying, clipp wires over the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset enters from the room of notebooks. This is John art studio. Windowless, with several easels holding paint in various states of completion. The walls are covered wi photos and finished canvases, except for one wall which i white. Somerset turns the lights off. There is a 16mm film projector on a table, facing the bla wall. Somerset turns the projector on. It clatters to lif running a piece of film. The film is spliced into a non-stop loop. Somerset watche wall, light strobing across him. The projector shows an image of clouds drifting, with str superimposed angels in flowing robes floating jerkily. It like an old, Hollywood version of heaven. The image switches abruptly to fire and tormented souls l around a pit of molten goo. Like Heaven, it's a scratched of film from Hollywood's early days. Somerset turns to examine one of the paintings on an ease http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ painting has been skillfully rendered, in small, controll brush strokes. It shows a modern city street, stylized, d The city is peopled by mutated humans and freakish beasts Sinners in the streets, killing, raping, pillaging. Build are burning, blood is being spilled. It's dense with deta Somerset walks to another painting which is covered by a cloth. He removes the cloth, uncovers a huge canvas. We d see the painting, but when Somerset does his features tur

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Somerset! Mills enters, tormented, weary. He stands in the projecto bright beam, holds an 8" by 10" print.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Somerset, we had him. Goddamn it. He hands a press pass and the photo to Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: The pass is a fake... we had him. Somerset looks at the photo, a picture of Mills and Somer the stairwell of the slum apartment building; the picture took when he posed as a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: We were that close to him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I know. Somerset motions to the huge canvas. Mills looks: The painting is frightening collage, thick with paint. Th photo of Mills and Somerset has been incorporated in bits pieces. Duplicate images: enlarged eyes, hands, faces. Th faces have been ripped, scratched, mutilated. Grainy eyes holes jabbed in them are mounted in paint beside chopped arms. Mills' head is on Somerset's body, and vice versa. like a sick, fragmented vision of a slaughter house floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of burnt-out row homes and warehouses. Stray, wil roam in a pack. A car turns down this street. It's John D car, moving fast. Its headlights go out and it cruises, avoiding garbage cans in the street. FOLLOW the dark car. Ahead, a few blocks away, we can see only lights in this neighborhood, the flashing reds, whit blues of police activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ John Doe brings the car to a stop. He watches the police work around the abandoned church. He gives no discernable reaction, puts the car in reverse. He looks behind as he back the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The refrigerator door is open. A male forensic uses tongs remove Zero's severed hand from behind soda cans and mayo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forensic walks through with the hand in a clear plast past a FEMALE SKETCH ARTIST who puts the finishing touche fairly accurate drawing of the balding John Doe.

dialogues.speaker: SKETCH ARTIST
dialogues.text: This is the guy? Mills stands over the artist. Sarah, Billy and two deputy detectives are at work in the room, photographing, search

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Make sure it gets around.

dialogues.speaker: SKETCH ARTIST
dialogues.text: You got it. Tomorrow morning, this city's good citizens will be on the lookout for Elmer Fudd.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (to Mills) We can't find anything to hang onto. No pay-stubs, no appointment books or calendars. Not even a book of phone numbers. And, you're not going to believe this...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: It's just... we haven't found any fingerprints yet. Not one.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You know, you're right. I don't believe it. Keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset reads one of Doe's notebooks. Three cops are loo through other notebooks from the shelves. Mills enters.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ We need to put more men on this.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'm working on it, alright. What have we got. Somerset bristles slightly at Mills' abrupt demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: We've got about five thousand notebooks in this room. And, as near as I can tell, each notebook contains two hundred and fifty pages.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Then, he must write about the murders. Somerset looks at the notebook, reads.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: "What sick, silly puppets we are, and what a gross stage we dance on. What fun we have, dancing around, not a care in the world. Not knowing that we are nothing. We are not what God intended." (turns pages) "On the subway today, a man came up to start a conversation. He was making small talk, this lonely man, talking about the weather and other things. I tried to be accommodating, but my head began to hurt from his banality. I almost didn't notice it had happened, but I threw up all over him. And I couldn't stop myself from laughing." (closes book) No dates indicated. They're placed on the shelves in no discernible order. He describes a scab on his arm for five pages, then writes about existential philosophy on the next. Mills walks. He looks into the adjoining paint room.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It's just his mind poured out on paper. Mills leans in the doorway, looking at Doe's strange artw

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You were right. He is preaching. The PHONE RINGS in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All attention is focused on the phone on Doe's desk. A ta http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker recorder is rigged to the receiver. Mills and Somerset en Mills walks over, pushes a button on the recorder, picks

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... hello?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from recorder) I admire you, David. Imagine my surprise on finding you at my doorstep. I admire you more and more every day.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay, John. Let's...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from recorder) No, no, no! You listen and don't talk. I suppose you found the painting and the photos. This is just as well. Now we all know we've all seen each other. (pause) I mean what I say. I do admire you. Long pause. Mills waits.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (V.O.,CONT)
dialogues.text: Oh, there is one other thing. Fourteen hundred thirty. West Eighty-sixth street. Apartment six-o-four. John Doe hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks around this femininely decorated bathroom. In the sink, objects covered in blood: a pair of scissors hypodermic needle, first-aid tape and gauze bandages, a b of anesthetic for use with the needle, a straight razor. Somerset moves from the sink, looks in the bathtub. The t shower walls are splattered with blood. The tub has a few inches of water in it. The water is cloudy red and bits o gauze float in it. Somerset jiggles the drain's knob. Some bubbles pop up from the clogged drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is in a dark mood. He and Dr. O'Neill stand by a WO who hangs by a noose from the ceiling. The woman's head h been bandaged sloppily with white gauze and tape. Her eye been left uncovered. The gauze is stained red in small sp http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|

Page 88 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ The woman hangs low, so her feet are inches from the floo piles of dried flowers and a cordless telephone lay. Ther chair knocked over behind her. O'Neill's going through his black bag. A violet, velvet c has been draped on the wall in the corner, behind a full mirror. The mirror reflects the corpse. A seven-pointed s is smeared in lipstick on the mirror's surface, with the DID NOT KILL HER, SHE WAS GIVEN A CHOICE below. Somerset enters from the bathroom, looks at the murder di

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Pride. Just like in the painting. Somerset nods. He walks to a dresser. The woman's purse s open and Somerset extracts her driver's license. He looks the photo. The woman in the picture is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You can see what he did. O'Neill steps up to the woman. He brandishes dull scissor The captain enters with two uniform cops. He looks around grim, clenching his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Cut her up... dressed the wounds. He put the noose around her neck and stood her on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: She had the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Call for help, and you'll live. But, you'll be mutilated.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Or, kick out the chair, and spare yourself a lifetime of hideousness. O'Neill's cutting the bandages on the woman's face. He pu them away in front. Mills looks, disgusted by the sight. Somerset sits in a chair, runs his fingers through his ha

dialogues.speaker: O'NEILL
dialogues.text: He cut off her nose to spite her face. And he did it very recently.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Alright, boys, you're running on empty. Go home. Just make sure you sleep with the phone between your knees. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bookstore is a labyrinth. Tables and shelves, mountai valleys of books. Books, new and used, hard and soft, in disorganized groups. CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYS. A few custome search for titles. Somerset walks, downcast, winds out of one aisle into ano he has his jacket over his shoulder, runs his fingers alo books as he goes. He pulls one book, The Merchant of Veni looks at it, replaces it. He looks down the aisle and is surprised to see Tracy. Tracy stands solemn, scanning book spines. Somerset appro

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Tracy? Tracy brightens a bit upon recognizing him.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Somerset. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I'm alright. I'm glad to see you found this place. I almost should have expected to run into you here, knowing that you teach English. Tracy looks up and around.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: It's so huge. It's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: This is why I moved into this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Don't you love the smell of all the old books. It smells like... like... I guess just old books, but, I love it. Somerset notices Tracy noticing his gun.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Forgive me. No matter how often I see guns, I can't get used to them.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Same here. Tracy laughs. She looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: If David's going to be back home soon, I http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ should get back. She starts down the aisle and Somerset walks with her.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I hope you'll come to dinner another night. Before you leave.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You can stay and browse a little longer, can't you? I mean... Tracy considers this as they enter an open area.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I... I hardly know anyone I can talk about books with anymore. I'd appreciate the company. Tracy stops. Somerset looks hopeful. Tracy is very tempte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelves and empty aisles of books. CLASSICAL MUSIC still

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The irony is, that after a day of the type of work he did, he'd come home and read me these morbid crime stories. Le Fanu's Green Tea. Murders in the Rue Morgue. MOVE TO the aisle marked MYSTERY, where Somerset and Trac leaning against shelves. They both hold books they've sel

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: My mother would give him hell... because I was young, and he was keeping me up till all hours, giving me nightmares.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Sounds like a father who wanted his son to follow in his footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: One birthday, he gave me a hardcover book called The Century of the Detective, by Jurgen Thorwald. It traced the history of detection as a science and it sealed my fate. Because it was real, and that a drop of blood or a piece of hair could solve a crime... was incredible to me. A CLERK looks down the aisle, then walks on.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ We're closing up, Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: David's going to wonder where I am.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I'll give you a ride.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: No. Please, don't bother.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I have to insist. If your husband found out I let you ride the subway at this hour he'd tear my head off. They make their way out of the aisle. Somerset chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I mean, literally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset's car stops at the corner of Mills' street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset puts the car in park. Tracy sits for a long time turns to face Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You've lived here for so long, Somerset. You know this city. I... Tracy can't quite figure how to put it.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: It's a hard place, Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: When David and I lived in Philadelphia, we could afford to live on the outskirts. But now... (pause) I hate it here. I feel scared, and I feel sick and... I hate it. Tracy wants to laugh, like it's silly, but can't pull it

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You have to put blinders on sometimes. Most times. But, keep in mind, Tracy, like tonight, there are small pockets of http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ sanity. Some bars and bookstores. Museums. Several last vestiges of civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Somerset's car, Tracy and Somerset continue talking. On the other side of the street, closer to the middle of block, John Doe's car is parallel parked at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the wheel, John Doe is slumped low, calmly watchin Somerset and Tracy. He can see them clearly from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks out through the windshield, fighting tears.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I've visited so many of the schools, looking for work, you know. And, the conditions are... horrible. I can't believe how bad it is. (pause) Children shouldn't have to grow up here.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You can always look into the private schools. You'll find something. Somerset gives her a handkerchief. She wipes her tears.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You're too hard on yourself, Tracy. She will not look at him, keeping herself under control.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It's okay to hate this city. It's natural. But, there is a bright side in all this. There is. You want to hear it? Tracy is able to muster a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Oh, God, yes. Please.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I can't think of another place that needs education more than this city. And you're a teacher. You can make a difference in a few people's lives. It's a very good thing. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Tracy leans to give him a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Somerset. They remain close, looking into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Somerset reaches to touch Tracy's face. They kiss. They k long time. Tracy wraps her arms around Somerset's neck. Somerset runs his fingers through Tracy's hair. They shar their sorrow. Tracy's tears run down her face. Finally, t part, opening their eyes. They know this is wrong. Somerset's hands are shaking. He grips the wheel, feels helpless.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Tracy. I'm sorry. Tracy's face is flushed. She is confused.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I... I better go. Tracy gets out, neglects to close the door, not looking b Somerset tries to come to his senses. He doesn't understa either, and his heart is aching. He adjusts the rearview to watch Tracy go. INSERT -- THROUGH REARVIEW MIRROR -- SOMERSET'S P.O.V. Tracy walks down the block, straightening her hair. She r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks away from the mirror. he holds his head in hands for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset leans to pull the door shut, puts the car in gea He drives, turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Doe watches Somerset's car leave. Doe turns his atte to Tracy, who hurries along the other side of the street. looks back, enters her apartment building, digs out her k She gets through the door and climbs stairs, disappearing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe gets out of his car. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ He looks both ways down the street, walks towards Mills' Tracy's building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Tracy are asleep in their bed. Mills' eyes shif under their lids. Rapid eye movement. A SOUND is HEARD from the other room. Mills awakens. He l still a moment, then gets up, slowly, reaches to take his off the bedside table. He grabs his pants from a chair, s into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills opens the bedroom door and enters quietly, gun held He moves, crouching. In the dark, objects in the room and shadows from windows complex, confusing patterns. Mills walks between moving boxes, attempting to remain si He aims the gun from point to point as he advances. He gets to a closet. Staying on one side, he opens the do points his gun. He carefully separates the clothing hangi there. Nothing. No one. He turns to look over the room. It's the first time we se in Mills' eyes -- real fear. The door to the apartment is wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills moves from his apartment, gun out, into the dark ha The coast is clear. He stays low, moves down the hall. He stops, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills shoves the rooftop door open. It creaks as it swing Mills moves out, backwards, looking to top the raised roo entrance, covering it with his gun. He moves around, sees nothing, walks to the edge of the roof and looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills returns to the bedroom, still holding his gun up. H looks at Tracy asleep in the bed. The room begins to RATT little as a subway train is again passing underground. He walks to the window and checks the lock. He halts. He the window and reaches out. The rattling is a bit LOUDER. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ From the fire escape, he picks up a bundle of thorny this wrapped with a rubber band. Mills realizes, Doe was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is plain, like the room Mrs. Gold was kept in. T door opens and Tracy and Mills enter. They look sleepy, carrying suitcases. A uniformed cop closes the door for t Mills goes to lay a suitcase on a table while Tracy looks around, depressed, distant. The lighting is bad. There ar decorations, no windows. A wide crack runs down one wall. Tracy sits down on the bed. Mills notices her discontent.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It won't be for long, honey. I swear. This is just till this is over.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I know. Mills goes to sit beside her. He puts his hand on her sho
