dialogues.text: You're wound way too tight on this, Mills.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Somerset... help me out here. Somerset looks at them. Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: It's over. The captain leaves. Mills is furious.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Damn it, Somerset. You know Johnny's fucking with us. He's pissing in our faces again!

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Slow up. You and I are, probably for the first time ever, in total agreement. He wouldn't just stop.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Well... what the fuck, man?

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: John Doe's only two murders away from finishing his masterpiece, right? But, can you even conceive of what might happen next? I mean, can you tell me how he's going to go about it?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I can tell you this; I recognize his lawyer. His name is Mark Swarr. He's the one who kept Zero out of prison. (pause) We'll wait for John Doe's plea. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is at the desk with his feet up, stares at the chal 1 gluttony (x) 5 lust (x) 2 greed (x) 6 wrath 3 sloth (x) 7 envy 4 pride (x) Clock on the wall says 4:45. Somerset packs books into bo preparing for his eventual departure. The captain opens t door and steps into the office. He clears his throat, like there is something very wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Somerset stand together. The captain is behind desk with the D.A., Martin Talbot, seated in front of him Swarr addresses them all, seems nervous, but in control.

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: My client says there are two more bodies... two more dead, hidden away. He will take Detective Mills to these bodies, but only Detective Mills. Only at six o'clock, today. Swarr wipes his brow with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: TALBOT
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: He says he admires you.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (to captain) This is all part of his game plan.

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: Mr. Doe claims that if the detective does not accept this offer, the bodies will never be found.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Frankly, counselor, I'm inclined to let them rot. Mills walks up into Swarr's face.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You like what you do for a living? http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 113 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Back off, Mills.

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: I'm required by law to serve my clients to the best of my ability, and to serve their interests. Mills eases off. Talbot is agitated, tapping a finger on gold tooth in his mouth. He looks at Swarr.

dialogues.speaker: TALBOT
dialogues.text: We don't make deals like this.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: We're going to have to pass.

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: My client... he also wishes that I inform you, if you do not accept, he will plead insanity, across the board.

dialogues.speaker: TALBOT
dialogues.text: Let him try. I'd like to see him try!

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: Come now, Martin. Even he knows, with the nature of these crimes, I could get him off with such a plea. Talbot stands, wringing his hands. Mills and Somerset are looking at each other, thinking it over.

dialogues.speaker: TALBOT
dialogues.text: I'm not letting this conviction slide. I can tell you that, right here and right now!

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: He says, if you accept, under his specific conditions, he will sign a full confession and plead guilty... right here, and right now. Talbot looks at Swarr with hatred.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Hold on... just a minute. Somerset turns to Talbot.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: If he were to plead insanity... this conversation is admissible. The fact http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ that he's blackmailing us with his plea...

dialogues.speaker: SWARR
dialogues.text: And, my client reminds you, two more people are dead. The press would have a field day if they found out the police didn't seem too concerned about finding them... giving them proper burial.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'll do it. I want to finish it. Somerset is thinking it through. He looks at Mills.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (to captain) Well... let's get the fucking lawyer out of the room, and we can talk about how this whole thing's going to go down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills' hand reaches to the sink to pick up a razor. He's shirtless, his chest covered in shaving cream. He starts shaving in front of a mirror. Somerset is behind him, smo

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: If John Doe's head splits open, and a U.F.O. flies out, I want you to have expected it.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No emotion. Stay as cold as ice.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I will. Somerset flicks ash in the sink. Mills finishes shaving. steps away from the sink and wipes his chest off with a t

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (very serious) Listen, Somerset... we've been through a lot together. And, I uh...

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I would like to make sweet love to you. Somerset walks away. Mills laughs. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Please... As they leave.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Give me a kiss on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills has his shirt off. A female technician, Josie, tape radio transmitter and microphone to his chest. Somerset sits nearby at one of the ready room desks. He w bullet-proof vest, is just finishing a check of his gun. putting the bullets back into it. Josie finishes prepping Mills. Mills presses the adhesive making sure it will hold. He puts on a shirt and bullet-p vest, fastens the velcro. Somerset stands, puts the gun in his hip holster. Mills picks up his own gun, checks it, holsters it. He wa Somerset take out a roll of antacids. Somerset pops a few

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Extremely. They look at each other. Mills holds out his hand. They s on it.

a The street is full of shadows as the sun is falling low. steps of the precinct house, a throng of reporters shifts anxiously. A line of policemen holds them back. The preci doors open. Martin Talbot arrives, escorted by cops. The press swarm lurches forward, flashbulbs explode. Talbot holds out his hands, quieting them, about to speak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills' car pulls out of the fenced parking lot. John Doe seated in the rear. The car speeds up on the street, turns onto an avenue, he http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page 116 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ into a canyon formed by tall buildings. At the corner, a parked. Somerset is at the wheel. He pulls out, follows Mills' ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California is dressed in full battle gear. He looks throu binoculars at the city below. The wind blows hard. He turns and runs to a sleek helicopter on the roof's hel climbs in the side door. The PILOT leans back from the co to hand him a helmet. California dons it, starts strappin himself in so he can lean out the open door.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Is this wind going to hurt us? The pilot cranks the helicopter's whining engine and the start to spin, churning the air.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Just makes the ride a little more fun. California hefts a high-powered automatic rifle as the ch lifts from the pad and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills drives, looking to the back seat through the rearvi mirror. A steel mesh partition separates front from back. John Doe sits with his hands cuffed. He is dressed in gra pants and a gray shirt. His feet are cuffed to a metal fa on the floor of the car. Rivulets of sweat pour down his He seems wired.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What's your story, Johnny? Who are you, really? Doe pushes his glasses back up the bridge of his nose, lo Mills' eyes in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter who I am. Who I am means absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset adjusts the volume on a radio receiver mounted o dash. He watches the road ahead, tailing Mills.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) What's your deal? You seem pretty fucking nervous. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) I want this to go well. It's very important to me, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chopper hovers amongst skyscrapers. California and th pilot are listening, through their helmet headsets.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from headset) You want this to go well? What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from headset) Turn right on this street. Stay in the left lane. California leans out the chopper door, using his binocula

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills' car weaves through traffic. Somerset's car isn't far behind, goes through a red light barely missing a truck. Other cars blow their horns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cellular phone on the passenger side is BEEPING. Somers pushes a button on the phone's panel. He puts on a headset/telephone, speaks into the mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from headset) Downtown and moving west. Looks like you're going to be crossing water.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: If we're on the bridge, you keep your distance. You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter hovers steady. California stows his binocu

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from headset) Cross the river before us if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: You got it. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 118 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ California taps the pilot's helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter dips, flying like a bullet over the city s heading towards the river and the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM HIGH ABOVE, we see traffic on the highway at the pol river's edge. Cards and trucks move like blood through ve DOWN CLOSER, we can see Mills' car in the flow. The car t into a lane of traffic on its way to the huge suspension Somerset's car is in close pursuit. UNDER THE BRIDGE, the police helicopter travels close to water, moving parallel to the bridge, but low, so that it of the sightline of the vehicles above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic is bumper to bumper. Somerset moves his headset mouthpiece to smoke a cigarette. He steers onto the bridg under the massive girders.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) For us to go pick up two more dead bodies, and have that be the end of it... just seems too boring for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the crest of the bridge, the sunset is crimson.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be sensational enough.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: Wanting people to pay attention, you can't just tap them on the shoulder. John Doe strains to turn, looks out the back window.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Sometimes you have to hit them in the head with a sledgehammer... and then you get their strict attention.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: What are you looking at, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: Looking back... at the city proper... http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Doe situates forward, holds his hands in front of his fac looking at his bandaged fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: And yet, no pillar of salt. (smiles to himself) Lost on you, isn't it? You've never read the Bible, have you, David?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I remember a lot of people reading it at me when I was a kid. I preferred the classic comic version myself. This is an affront to Doe, angers him. Mills sees it, lik

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I used to have "Godspell" on an eight- track tape. Does that count? Doe leans forwards, fury building in him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: You make me sick.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Sit back, freak. Mills slams his fist against the partition. Doe sits back

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Ignorant heathen.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Right, right. I forgot. You think these murders were for God. Right? (pause) I'm asking you seriously. You really think what you did was God's good work? Doe looks out the window at other cars, refuses to answer He's pressing the tips of his forefingers into his thumbs causing blood to drip from under the bandages.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: The Lord works in mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting dark. We've been in this section of factorie before, with John Doe. The police helicopter soars overhe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ California's looking down, wearing night-vision goggles.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA'S P.O.V.
dialogues.text: The goggles allow California to see clearly into the maze by buildings, yards and worksheds below. No one in sight.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuck, man... there's about a thousand places to be ambushed out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headlights are off. Mills' car's red brake lights are ahead on this industrial road.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from headset) I don't see anything... not yet.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (in mouthpiece) A quick sweep is all we get. Clear out now. You're right in front of us. Somerset reaches to turn up the volume on his radio recei Mills is HEARD SINGING "Jesus Christ Superstar," loud. So allows a very faint smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills drives along, singing.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Superstar... who in the world do you think you are? Jesus Christ, Superstar... Doe's in the back seat, trying to bear it, steaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chopper goes high, away, over the industrial area. It moves to the other side of the factories and settles i over the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills' tune comes to a conclusion. Somerset slows the car sees Mills' brake lights go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) We can walk from here. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (in mouthpiece) You stay out of this unless I call you in, California. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from headset) You're in charge. Somerset takes off the headset/phone, stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset gets out. He looks through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET'S P.O.V.
dialogues.text: Mills' car has stopped under the lights of a junk-yard. M gets out. He walks to unlock the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) Alright, Somerset. Going for a stroll.

dialogues.speaker: AT MILLS' CAR
dialogues.text: Mills opens the passenger door. Doe looks out.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Lean on your side. Hands behind your head and lock your fingers together. Doe obliges. Mills moves to unchain Doe's feet, cautious.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET'S P.O.V.
dialogues.text: Mills lets Doe out. Doe does a deep knee bend to loosen h legs. Mills takes out his gun.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) Where are we going? Doe points with handcuffed hands, at a path through the j yard, towards warehouses. Mills motions with his gun.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.,CONT)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) Lead the way. Doe starts walking. Mills follows, keeping the gun on Doe lose sight of them behind the junk-yard's massive pieces.

dialogues.speaker: AT SOMERSET'S CAR
dialogues.text: Somerset lowers his binoculars. He gets back in the car, the lights off, drives slowly towards Mills' car. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills follows Doe past rusting collections of machines. W this walk with Doe before, through this metallic bone-yar

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: It's right this way. Mills is on edge. His eyes search the towering, twisted j Sharp edges reach for the sky. Glass breaks under their f

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: So far, so good. SOUNDS of BOATS on the river can be HEARD. Doe's heading the alleyway created by two warehouses beyond the junk-ya Doe nears the alleyway. It is pitch dark. Doe stops befor entering, turns to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: In here. Mills steps up, keeping his distance from Doe. He can't s thing in the blackness ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You go first. Doe faces the alley. He starts walking. We MOVE with him goes. He's counting silently to himself, moving his lips. Mills walks behind Doe, keeping a sharp eye out in all directions. He's about ten feet behind Doe, keeping his g trained on the back of Doe's skull.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Tell me where we're going. Doe continues walking, counting his steps, a bit quicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset has pulled along Mills' car, at the junk-yard.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) Slow down, Johnny. Stop right there. (pause) I said stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe walks on. Mills is behind, walking to close the gap. can HEAR the faint SOUND of RUSHING WATER. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'll blow your head off right now! Doe stops abruptly. He spins on his heels, facing Mills. Mills is getting closer, pumped, ready to pull the trigge Doe reaches up with his hands, takes off his glasses. He them in one hand. The SOUND of the WATER is LOUDER. Mills is about six feet from Doe, and knows something's w John Doe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: What... Doe takes one step backwards and falls, straight down, disappears in the blink of an eye.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks towards the far off alleyway, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) Motherfucker! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills stands facing the open manhole cover Doe disappeare A torrent of water rushes by underground. Mills fires a f futile shots into the water, out of his mind with rage. H pulls back the top of his bullet-proof vest, exposing the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: He's gone, Somerset! He's in the water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset leaps out, takes out his gun. FOLLOW as he runs the junk-yard as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (from receiver) I'm going in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chopper's over the river. California listens intently

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ (from headset) I have to go in after him! STATIC CRACKLES LOUD in his headset, then it GOES DEAD. California grips his mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Somerset, what's going on down there?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An underground pipe-way. Mills tries to swim, is mostly c in the flow. He's battered against the sides of the pipe, holding his breath desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW Somerset as he charges onwards through the junk-ya stumbling over pieces of metal. He runs towards the alley

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WATER ROARS. A square pool of water churns. A moment, the Mills rises, gasping, choking. He's disoriented, furious, waving his gun, expecting Doe to be right on top of him. No one around. Mills looks. This is some sort of unmanned water switching station. the walls are covered in catwalk drainage pipes and tunnels. Some tunnels and pipes spew w down into the central pool, others are sealed shut. Mills pulls himself from the central pool to a concrete spillway. He stands up, searching. Doe could be anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Come on, Johnny! I'm right here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a plastic bag with an automatic pistol and extra inside hanging from a protruding shut-off valve. John Doe hands tear the bag open, taking the contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset enters the alley, short of breath. He points his in front of him, fearful. Moving slowly.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Mills!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California is enraged, looks towards the pilot.

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: God damn it! Let's do something! http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Somerset said wait!

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: Fuck that! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: I don't know! Just go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills climbs onto a catwalk. He passes tunnels, looking d each, intense, ready to kill. A waterfall flows and over other end of the catwalk. Mills stands, looking over the railing at the central poo other tunnels. He points his gun and fires into a far tun

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Come on! Let's do it! You and me! A figure appears in the center of the waterfall behind Mi

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I'm not going to let you win this! John Doe steps out of the waterfall, putting on his glass He seems calm, unloads his gun into Mills' back... BLAM, Mills twists, blown forward by the bullets slamming into bullet-proof vest. BLAM, BLAM, BLAM... he stumbles, tryin turn and fire back, but bullets strike him down and he fa the floor of the catwalk, gun falling from his hand. CLICK. Doe's gun is empty. The gunshots echo. Mills lays there on his stomach, pounded, blacking out, the hot bull his vest smoking and sizzling from the water splashing th Doe moves quickly, starts searching Mills' pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset comes upon the open manhole. Water rushes by.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The central pool bubbles, undulating. Somerset surfaces, inhaling, bringing his gun up. He looks. No one in sight. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Mills! Pull out! His voice reverberates, barely heard against the roaring he swims to the edge, climbs out. He walks, looking...

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (pleading) Pull out now! Somerset looks up, and freezes up on seeing -- -- Doe's handcuffs hang, swinging, on the rail of the cat above, with Mills' radio transmitter and wire tied to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset runs to his car, driven, gasping for breath, sti soaking wet. He stops for one second, looks. Not too far away, the police helicopter flies low to the turning in wide circles. Somerset climbs into the car, starts it up. He drives awa leaving his lights off. The engine protests loudly, force its limit. The car disappears in darkness. The police helicopter circles, useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church stands elegant at night, when its decayed stat partially hidden. Small shafts of light escape from holes the facade and just into the blackness. Somerset is out of his car. He strides towards the church checks his gun as he goes. FOLLOW with him, getting close the church. He climbs the stairs. Somerset steps up and kicks the church doors open, met by tremendous blast of light --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flickering orange light from hundreds of once tall orange candles, now burnt low. They greet Somerset, in the churc old candle racks, on the floor, on the altar and all thro the pews. Somerset's eyes try to adjust to the light. He holds his ready, walks down the long center aisle.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Somerset. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Doe sounds far, his voice echoing from the front of the c

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Where's David?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He's here. With me.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Tell me what you want. Somerset can see through the heat warp. Doe stands facing from the altar.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: What do I want? The same you... I want an ending. Stay where you are. Put your gun on the floor and slide it all the way down here. Somerset obeys, bends, slides the gun down the aisle till hits the bottom altar stair. He keeps walking, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I want to see him. Show me Mills. On the altar, Doe is sweating hard, standing over Mills. is slumped forward on the floor, unconscious. His bullet- vest has been removed. Mills' hands are tied tight together in front of him, tie one end of the thick rope suspended from the ceiling. Doe the other end of the rope, has his gun tucked under his b

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: You're an intelligent man, Somerset. You understand what you're a part of, don't you? When this is finished, it will seem surreal, but it will be a whole, crystalline reality. And, no one will be able to deny it, no matter how hard they try. Doe's voice is thick with passion. Somerset is about half down the aisle, still moving.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You're a murderer. That's all. The only way you've distinguished yourself is by your particular brutality. Doe walks across the altar.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: You know that's not true. You know.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ You're killing innocent people, and I should admire you? You're doing it because it gives you pleasure. That's the only purpose... your sick pleasure. Doe picks up a container of gasoline, looks out at Somers

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: Stay where you are! Somerset stops.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I won't deny my personal desires. I won't. Doe begins dousing Mills with gasoline, covering Mills' b clothing. Mills stirs, coming to. He coughs, choking on t gas and fumes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: But, I don't mourn the victims in this any more than I mourn the thousands who died in Sodom and Gomorrah. Somerset looks fearful. He starts approaching again.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: All you've done is cause more misery and pain! You've given people all the more reason to believe there is no God! Somerset eyes his gun at the bottom of the stairs. Doe sees Somerset moving, throws the gas can away, takes gun. Doe walks to the edge of the altar, all the time hol his end of the rope.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: Stop! Somerset is twitching with anger, looking at the gun abou fifteen feet in front of him. Mills manages to look up, weak, his eyes barely able to o because of the stinging gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Somerset? Doe takes one step down off the altar. Somerset is still forward, hands out away from his body.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Do you really think I'm just going to let this happen?! You think I'm going to let him die? http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: Yes. Doe fires his gun and the bullet slams into the front of Somerset's bullet-proof vest. Somerset flies back, knocki over a rack of candles on his way to the floor. Doe walks quickly back onto the altar.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Motherfucker! Mills tries to grab at Doe as he passes, but Doe turns an Mills in the ribs. Mills cringes in pain. Somerset lays in the aisle, on his stomach, gasping. He c catch his breath, his twisted face pressed against the fl

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: How can you speak of God, Somerset? When was the last time you spoke His name? Mills tries to rub the gas out of his eyes with his bound His mind works feverishly. He looks around to see where h then he searches the floor. We can see, inside his open s the bleeding, upside-down cross Doe has cut into his ches Doe walks back to shout angrily down at Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: When did you last speak His name? Was it in prayer? Or, did you say the Lord's name after you stubbed your big toe? Or, did you use His name to curse another man? Somerset holds his chest, blinking, trying not to black o Mills finds a piece of broken stained glass on the floor. picks it up, palms it, still choking on gasoline. Doe walks over to the statue of Saint Jerome Emiliani, pu the rope from above so it goes taut and Mills' arms raise his head. Doe wraps the rope around Emiliani's arm.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill you, Johnny. I'm going to see you dead. Doe begins twisting the loose end of the rope around the

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: The irony, David, is that you policemen and I want the same things. But, you http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker are so short sighted. In this city, where you can see a deadly sin on every street corner... and in every home, we want repentance. Mills clutches the glass piece and starts cutting the rop above his hands.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: We want good over evil. We want values instilled in the children. We want a world where a man or woman can lead a decent life. (pause) Wisdom, understanding, counsel, fortitude, knowledge, piety, and fear of the Lord. Such simple concepts. Why are they non-existent? Somerset manages to life his head, struggles to his knees

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (weakly) Let him go, God damn you. Doe checks to make sure the rope around Saint Emiliani is tightening the knots.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: There were two men once, who had wonderful gardens. Two gardens of flowers that went on as far as the eye could see. Beautiful gardens... the fragrance was inspiration in itself. Doe stands behind Emiliani, heaves against the statue. Mills watches, gritting his teeth, rubbing the glass agai rope, fingers bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: But, both gardens were beset by problems. Weeds started to take root, and there were infestations of insects and diseases. The gardens started to turn putrid. And, one man fought to save his garden, because he could never forget how it once was. Everyday he cut the weeds, and killed the insects. Fought the diseases. Doe finally topples the statue, down the altar stairs, an other end of the rope pulls Mills upwards, screaming in p Mills is held, about eight feet in the air, legs dangling

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: That man never had a beautiful garden http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm|
Page 131 of 138  "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker again.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

The other man plowed his garden under. (pause) He plowed it under the soil. over. Somerset gets to his feet, He started steadying himself on a pew. Doe walks across the altar, picks up a long metal pole wi thick wick and candle snuffer on the end. He lights the wick from a near candle. The flame burns long and thin. He loo down at Somerset, takes out his gun.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Stay there, Somerset. Or, I'll kill him right now. Doe holds the flaming pole up, near Mills. Somerset stops. He looks up at Mills. Mills is straining. He nods to Somerset, Mills cutting at the rope.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: and Somerset sees Alright... you don't have to do this, John. You've already made

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: Do you think I chose this? begin to understand how painful It's like... existence has been? your point. Can you even my like having every sense heightened beyond comprehension. Doe lowers the flame, standing below and attention focused on Somerset. beside Mills, with his

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: So that the your throat like bile. sweet it... the marrow. So,

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: You're insane. That's why.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: (seething) No! You're wrong! Mills continues cutting, bleeding, almost through the rop http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| stench of the street coats sugar is so it makes your bones ache to He Page 132 of 138 "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ begins to swing his feet slightly, his body swaying.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I was chosen. And I've wished a thousand times I could have been a normal man. Like David Mills, a common man... with a common life. But, wishing that is my sin. I can't have it and I shouldn't. Doe steps towards Mills.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Don't do this!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE
dialogues.text: I meant what I said. I admire David Mills. I envy David Mills. (pause) Envy is my sin.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: No! Just as Doe is to put the flame to Mills, the rope is fin cut through. Mills drops, swinging his legs forward, smas Doe in the face, knocking Doe's glasses off. Mills hits the floor with a thud. Somerset runs forward.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: David, get out! Doe has fallen back, dropping the metal pole. Mills scram to his feet and charges at Doe, shouting. Doe squints, screaming, raises his gun. Fires twice! The bullets catch Mills in mid-run, and carry him off his backwards. Somerset grips his own gun, just as Mills' body falls, tu off the altar area and down the stairs in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: No! Somerset lets out a scream of pain and rage that chokes i throat. He falls to his knees and halts Mills' body. Somerset's shaking, unable to breathe, turning Mills over cradling his head in his arms. Tears come to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: David... David? Please... http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ On the altar, Doe throws his gun away. he starts feeling him, unsteady, looking for his glasses. Mills' eyes are closed. He is still, bloody. He swallows. With one gasp, without a word, he is dead. Somerset looks up at Doe, vision blurred by rage and tear Doe stands, putting on his glasses, faces Somerset. Somerset lays Mills' body down. Stands, walks up towards altar, raises his gun.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET, (CONT)
dialogues.text: You. Doe stands, quaking, teeth clenched, fists balled up. He for the bullets, falls to his knees. The gun trembles in Somerset's hand as Somerset brings th barrel to Doe's face. A millisecond's pause. Somerset cha the angle of fire. BLAM, he blows John Doe's arm to piece splattering explosion. Doe screams, falling back, on the altar floor.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWED FROM FAR BACK IN THE CHURCH
dialogues.text: The entire church with its candles frames the torture: Somerset walks to where Doe flops horribly, bleeding. Som aims, shoots Doe in the leg. Doe screams, rolling, trying crawl away, knocking over candle racks. Somerset follows. shoots Doe's other leg. He shoots Doe in the other arm. F begin to rise and spread quickly amongst the pews. Doe continues to spasm, wrenching, hand slapping the bloody f BLAM, BLAM, BLAM. Somerset steps back from Doe, overturns rack of candles on top of him. He steps away. Watching. Flames begin rising on Doe's clothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Doe's face, covered in blood, twisted in agony, helpless, rising. He continues screaming. His glasses crack from the heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke billows from the windows. The fire is moving quickl ravenous. It's just starting to light up the night. From the front door, Somerset walks weeping, carrying Mil body in his arms. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seven deadly sin tableau burns. Flames cause the paint to bubble and blacken. Gluttony, g and sloth are already halfway gone. Flames eat at pride, lust. Wrath and envy are being consumed. Wrath goes last. A man bloodied hands, in tones of blue. Flames devour it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A field of blue. Cops in orderly rows. The funeral of Dav Mills. Many police officials and politicians stand in tri Somerset is here, in his dress blue uniform. He stares fo still numb, beaten. Rifles are raised by a corps of rifle Blanks explode from the barrels. They reload in unison. Somerset looks towards the grace where Mills' casket lies an American flag. Tracy is there. Tracy stands surrounded by strangers at the grave-site. H head is lowered. She cries. Each blast of the rifle salut causes her to react with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral is over. Somerset stands at the edge of the graveyard, looking at the distant city. Behind him, the mourners are still filing out to their cars. The captain approaches. He comes to stand beside Somerset similarly solemn.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I don't know if I should do this. (pause) We found the motel room Doe must have been staying in after you found his apartment. Somerset hasn't acknowledged the captain, still looking a

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Anyway... we found this in his belongings. The captain takes out a sealed envelope. Somerset takes i On the envelope: DETECTIVE SOMERSET, handwritten, in red http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy and Somerset stand near a moving truck in front of apartment building. MOVERS carry Tracy's belongings to th truck. Mills' car is attached to be towed behind.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: I wish I could say something... (pause) Something to... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I'll be okay. Somerset nods.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: We'll keep in touch. I'11l come visit.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I'll write to you when we get there.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself. (pause) Take care of the baby. Tracy nods. There's nothing left for them to say. They're empty. It's time for them to give a gesture, a kiss, or a to say goodbye, but neither makes the first move.

dialogues.speaker: MOVER
dialogues.text: That's all, Mrs. Mills. We got everything. Movers latch up the back of the truck while the driver cl in and fires up the engine.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Somerset. Somerset walks away. Tracy walks away, gets in the passen side of the moving truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidewalks jammed with people, hurrying. Somerset walks in fog, hands in his pockets. He stops at a corner, but does cross. He stands there, looks up. At the city around him. The buildings towering over him. At the cars, buses and taxies racing in the streets, blow http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ their horns and spouting soot. Somerset reaches into his jacket pocket, takes out the en from John Doe. He studies it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SOMERSET
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh... man... He opens it. He takes out a small note, handwritten. It r PLOW THEM UNDER. Somerset looks up again, mortified, fighting to keep cont his emotions. He looks around: At the miserable people, walking past him. At a man at the top of the subway station stairs, sitting cardboard box, holding out a cup, rattling the change ins A father passes by, holding his young son's hand. Somerse turns to watch them as they pass. The gather reaches to p the boy up and carry him. The boy holds tight. For some reason, this makes Somerset ache with sorrow. The father hugs his son to him, kisses him on the cheek. boy returns the kiss, with great affection. Somerset watches them disappear in the mass of humanity. looks back at the note in his hand. He tears the note up, into little pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck moves along in steady traffic. Tracy sits besid driver. She looks out at the city across the river. She reaches into her pocket, takes out a small manila env She opens the envelope and slides two keys on a keychain into her palm. She's looking at the keys when she notices something abou envelope. She reopens it, takes out a small folded piece paper. She unfolds it: It is the piece of wallpaper with the pale rose at its ce She smiles very faintly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars roll by in the street. Cops come and go. http: //www.dailyscript.com/scripts/seven_early.htm| Page "Seven", unproduced draft, by Andrew Kevin Walker 11/13/ Somerset walks up the stairs into the precinct house.

dialogues.speaker: END
